Definition: pas/imp. suffix.
abbreviation of ʻākau, north, as in surveying reports.

simulative ligature in the sequence 'verb + noun' compounds; particle for forming verb compounds; like, similar to. 
usu. verb + ā + noun:
     ʻaiāmanō eat like a shark, have a prodigious appetite
     ʻaiāpuaʻa eat like a pig
     hanuāpuaʻa breathe like a pig, gasp for breath
     heleāiʻa (= holoāiʻa) swim like a fish
     heleāwai  flow like water
     hikiāloa long-range, long-term
     holoāiʻa swim like a fish
     huliāmahi turn like a strong (cock); cooperation, strength
     kaheāwai flowing like water
     kaʻiālupe lit. to lead like a kite (support a person between two others)
     kūākanaka turn into a man, look like a man
     kūākiʻi stand with hands on hips... like a statue...
     kūāmaʻi very sick
     mokuāhana dividing into factions
     mokuāhua grief, pity, disappointment
     mokuāwai burst as floodwaters, rush as a crowd
     paiālewa tossed here and there (lit., lift into space)
     paʻiāumi beat one's chest (as in lamentation)
     pukaāmaka to appear to the eyes (seal a relationship of two families by marriage)
    ʻumiāpuaʻa strangled like pigs
also verb + ā + verb:
     uhaiāholo chase like running
     uluāhewa mania, delusion; grow wild and lush
pejorative suffix, often written wā after o or u. see ʻaiā, haiā, hainā, huā (huwā), kauā (kauwā), lonoā, (lonowā), mākoeā, naʻauʻauā (naʻauʻauwā), poluā (poluwā)
personal article occurring only after the preposition i, written ia.

• jaw, cheekbone. 
   • fig., to talk a lot, jabber, jibber jabber.
an instrument made of smooth bone, formerly used for abortion, lancing, or bleeding. also āʻōʻō, piercing ā.
mold found in souring foods, especially poi, generally known as Oidium lactis or Oospora lactis, but now called Geotrichum candidum.
prefix to numbers from one through nine, especially for counting in series.
in the nature of (as hina, white, ʻāhina, somewhat white, gray; pali, cliff, ʻāpali, like a cliff). There are many examples, as ʻālewalewa, ʻālualua, ʻāmokumoku, ʻāoʻo, ʻāpono, ʻāwela.
fiery, burning; fire; to burn, blaze. fig., to glitter or sparkle, as a gem; to burn, as with jealousy or anger.
ʻaʻā lava, or lava rock, as distinguished from smooth unbroken pāhoehoe lava (formerly preceded by ke); to flow, as ʻaʻā lava.

red-footed booby bird (Sula sula rubripes), brown booby (Sula leucogaster plotus), masked or blue-faced booby (Sula dactylatra personata); all indigenous and also breeding elsewhere. Legendary birds believed to have taken the shape of this bird are   ʻā ʻaia, ʻāʻaiʻanuheakāne and 
ʻāʻaianuinūkeu; ʻā by some were considered ʻaumākua. see also (Kep. 33).
young stage of damselfish (ʻāloʻiloʻi).
Oh! Well! Ah! Er …
to drive, as fish or cattle.
the letter "a".

• small root, rootlet, 
   • vein, artery, nerve, tendon, muscle. 
   • fig., womb, offspring.
belt, girdle, waist; to gird, tie on.
• to burn, blaze, glow;  fire;    • staring, as eyes.    • fig., angry; fury.
ʻaʻā lava; stony, abounding with ʻaʻā lava.
Sirius, a zenith star that passes over Tahiti and Raʻiātea, formerly believed used by navigators; one of the brightest stars in the heavens. see Sirius for var. names.
young stage of damselfish (ʻāloʻiloʻi).
dumbness, inability to speak intelligibly, a dumb person (Puk. 4.11) ; dumb, silent, still; to stutter and stammer, as a dumb person.
dwarf, small person; dwarfish, small.
demented, panic-stricken.
male ʻōʻō bird.
network of veins.
clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond; vascular bundles in taro corm, chaff, tissue; fibrous, stringy.
scion or shoot of sandalwood.
bag for carrying fire-making equipment (ʻaʻa, bag, and ahi, fire).
second or third crop, as of taro; taro patch where the taro has been pulled up.
the sound ay that infants make in calling for attention; to make this sound.
netted carrier for a calabash, made of sennit or olonā cord. More commonly called kōkō.
burning fire.
thatch purlin; rails, as in a fence.
container, as for pia, arrowroot starch; to put pia in small packages so that it may keep sweet.
to speak reproachfully, contemptuously, deride, jeer; jealous challenge.
regal attire, a royal robe, a type of colored tapa worn by people of rank.
a fabulous being said to have had extraordinary strength, to have come from the center of the earth, and to have been the creator of all dwarfs.
head shield; protection for the head in war, as helmet, shield.
aching veins, varicose veins.
armor, war garment.
tendon. lit., pulled vein.
a long malo or ornamented band made of the soft makaloa rush; to put on or wear this garment.
full regalia, dress uniform. Lit., full professional garment.
garment made of pāwehe, patterned mat; mat made of soft material and woven in the pāwehe pattern; to put on and wear this garment.
bright, vivid, as of contrasting colors.
demented.
legendary bird believed to have taken the shape of the ʻā, booby bird.
legendary bird. Lit., caterpillar eater of Kāne.
inferior, weak, said of breadfruit or fruit with a weak stem that may fall before maturity; weak object. (Kep. 93) fig., of persons dying before their time.

• surly, cranky, roiled, complaining, irritable, peevish, bad tempered, cantankerous, cross; 
   • severe, as labor.
rocky undersea cavern. (PH 219), (Malo 26).
wood of the naio, bastard sandalwood.
a hook nibbler, said of small fish that nibble away the bait; to nibble at a hook.
repeated plucking.
insatiable lust.
to get into action.
vein, blood vessel.
a root running horizontally that produces roots below and above; a rhizome, creeping root.
name of a combination of diseases: liver complication resulting in hardening of the veins, bloody dysentery accompanied by fever.
varicose veins. lit., raised veins.
winds.
name of a wind accompanied by rain associated with Hilo. lit., earth fragrance.
a fish (no data; perhaps a local name for one of the chaetodons).
young of the ʻalaʻihi fishes.
wild, demented person; uncivilized.
insipid, unsavory, tasteless.
large, plump.
wind name.

velvety-green, succulent-appearing seaweeds, one of several species of Codium. It yields a red liquid when placed in a container overnight with brine, after chopping or pounding. Both the liquid and the seaweed are well liked, being eaten plain or with other food. (KL. line 47) ʻaʻalaʻula is the common name on Kauaʻi and Maui, wāwaeʻiole elsewhere.
pulse. lit., leaping vein.
redup. of ʻali₁; scarred, marked, grooved; depression, groove; wattles of a fowl; slight depression under the gills of a fish.

native hardwood shrubs or trees (Dodonaea, all species), 30 cm to 10 m [1-33 ft] high, more or less sticky at branch tips; leaves narrow, 2 to 10 cm [¾"-4"] long; flowers small; fruit a yellow, red, or brown papery capsule about 1 cm long and with two to four wings. Fruit clusters are made into leis with their own leaves or ferns and worn in the hair. (Neal 536–7), (FS 57). symbol of independent people of Kaʻū. (Wight)
scarred.
large, fat, weak, as a fat person.
clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond; European cloth.
nerve. lit., brain vein.
ravine, small stream, valley, depression.
a large, black, edible crab (Grapsus grapsus tenuicrustatus) that runs over shore rocks.
to spread and relax, as the fingers. [The ʻaʻama crab was offered in sacrifices so that the gods would loosen (aʻama) and grant the request.]
to stare or glare with wide-open eyes, as in desire, fear, or intent to frighten; one who does so.
coconut-leaf or pandanus-leaf bag used for carrying birds.
broken blood vessel.
purse. (Bib.)
young clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond; gauze, as of a veil; diaphanous cloth. lit., ʻaʻa portion.
snakeskin; slime, as on fresh water. lit., lizard ʻaʻa.
to use abusive language, revile, malign.
to criticize maliciously; malign.
clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond.
overbearing, arrogant, bold, defiant, daring; bully.
greedy, voracious.
uncultivated bananas.
valve of a vein.
ʻaʻā lava or flow, volcanic.
warped, curved.
to learn quickly, to catch the meaning quickly, apt.
coconut-shell cup; cuplike.
to warp, bend, ruffle.
arrow case, quiver.
girdle, belt. lit., loin belt.
capsular ligament.
knots in a fish net.
sharp or waterworn, coarse gravel or rock.
to move here and there, wander, rove; to ripple, as the sea.
coarse, as wrinkled or blotched skin; lean, as fish.
wrasse fishes, Hawaiian hogfish (Bodianus bilunulatus), considered ʻaumākua by some. The name ʻaʻawa may be qualified by the terms ʻeʻa, hai ʻeʻa, lelo, ule holu (pliable penis).
name given for an insect that destroys potatoes.

a native tree (Pittosporum hosmeri and its varieties), about 6 m high, with leaves 10 to 25 cm by 1.5 to 6 cm, shiny and wrinkled above, brown-wooly beneath; small, clustered, cream-colored flowers; ovoid fruits about 5 cm long, each with two to four thick valves containing orange pulp and black oily seeds.

several native trees, the soapberry (Sapindus saponaria f. inaequalis), and all species of Zanthoxylum (also known as Fagara, Zanthoxylum having yellowish wood formerly used for digging sticks and spears); seeds of all (largest in the soapberry) are black, round, and used for leis.
northeast tradewind.
blight.
replacement of e in songs (commonly written a e, but a glottal stop is pronounced before ʻe).
Maui name for maua₂, trees.
• sap wrung from seaweed or leaves of plants such as taro;    • liquid remaining after dregs have settled, as of pia, arrowroot starch;    • saliva, drooling of the mouth.
to rise, of the tide.

a native fern (Polypodium pellucidum) commonly seen at Kīlauea Volcano. It has oblong fronds 15 to 40 cm long, once divided into about fifteen or more pairs of oblong segments, each of which bears many round fruit dots.
shoots from main root portion of the wauke plant.
to rise up; to raise the head; to come up from under water.
cord, as used in joining two or more nets into a larger one.

• a prolonged sound, 
   • wail; 
   • to prolong, 
   • stretch.
andante.
mixing of a dark or brilliant color with a lighter one, as feathers in a lei; of dark hair of a young person with streaks of gray; to mix, as drinks.
a kind of banana with green and white striped leaves and fruits.
a fish (no data).

a small native shrub (Lycium sandwicense) growing near salt marshes and among rocks near the sea. It has light-colored bark; succulent, narrow pale-green leaves about 2.6 cm long; small white to blue-tinted flowers; and small red berries.
water hyssop, a succulent herb (Bacopa monnieria). Niʻihau cf. (Neal 759).
a small green fish resembling the hīnālea, used as pani (food or drink taken to finish a medical treatment) for certain diseases of children of the ʻea type.
name of a star (no data).
a variety of wild sweet potato, good only as pig food.
fine net, as used for ʻōpelu and maomao fish; it was held open at the mouth by kuku, stretching poles.
chant refrain.
chant ending.
a step, as on a carriage; running board of an automobile.
place where sea and land meet; water's edge.
ancient type of tapa (no data).
falcon, vulture.
eagle.
alto.
golden eagle.
directional part. aʻe + demon. lā.
agreement, contract, truce, accord, deal; to come to an agreement; contracted.
rotten, of eggs that do not hatch due to infertility. fig., spoiled, worthless.
name for the trade wind. see ex., kiʻekiʻe.
just now, lately; nearby, not far; ordinary, insignificant.
stilts.
Hawaiian stilt bird (Himantopus mexicanus knudseni), an endemic subspecies of stilt, formerly common on the main Hawaiian Islands, endangered.
train of a dress (origin uncertain).
to be well supplied with comforts and necessities.
a kind of fine tapa, used in kuni and other ceremonies, as for divining with pebbles.
sandy beach.
possessing a family or lineage.
aha (exclamation of surprise).
meeting, assembly, gathering, convention, court, party. Many types of ʻaha are listed below.
a prayer or service whose efficacy depended on recitation under taboo and without interruption. The priest was said to carry a cord (ʻaha).
millepede, so called because it coils itself up like a string.
any of the needlefishes of the family Belonidae. The young are called ʻahaʻaha. Varieties are qualified by the terms holowī, mele, and uliuli.
design supposed to resemble the continuing track of a duck, carved on tapa beaters.
four (usually in counting in series): four times.
to pant, to breathe hard with heat, as a dog.
cordage.
to sit with back stiff and upright, arms akimbo, head up, as with haughty air of superiority; to sit cross-legged; to stand with hands on hips (considered rude and overbearing).
young of the ʻaha, a fish.
Holy Communion, Lord's Supper; feast of the Lord.
Feast of weeks.
feast of consecration or dedication, as of a house, church, canoe, or fish net.
feast of dedication.
commemorative or anniversary feast.
feast given at the time of a boy's subincision. Called in Christian times ʻahaʻaina ʻoki poepoe.

feast given at the completion of a student's first work (as mat, quilt, tapa, net), or of a child's first fish catch; one purpose was to ask the gods to grant greater knowledge and skill to the craftsman. lit., feast to care for.
feast given to ask pardon of the gods. lit., feast to forgive sins.
Feast of Tabernacles. (Bib.)
initiation feast.
feast held after completion of a joint project or cooperative undertaking, especially harvest.

feast given to honor those who prepared the feast and served, the workers being served by those who had celebrated before; also a feast to celebrate completion of a particularly laborious project. lit., feast for tired persons.
funeral feast, intended to comfort the mourners.
wedding feast or reception.
feast given shortly after the birth of the first child, intended to clear the way (māwaewae) of misfortune for that child and for all others to follow.
Feast of the Passover. (Bib.)
Holy Communion. lit., feast of bread.
feast on the first birthday of a child, or to celebrate any anniversary. lit., feast for completion of the year.

feast given principally to break the monotony of country life; those instigating the feast would sprinkle (pī wai) their friends with a little water; those sprinkled brought food to the feast or, later, gifts of coins.
graduation feast, as for hula dancing or lua fighting.
feast of tears, held on the first anniversary of a death, a happy occasion, as the death by this time has been accepted by the family.
design said to resemble duck tracks, carved on tapa beaters.
district court.
convention of delegates; name for American presidential conventions.
syllables repeated in chants, usually at ends of verses, similar to ēhē; also ahana and ahana kōkō lele, both meaningless.
a taunting singsong teasing phrase, used especially by children, meaning "Oh! Oh! Aha! Shame on you! You are going to catch it!"; as a verb, to tease.
cord support for gourd water bottles.
ceremonial measuring of the dimensions of a mana house within a place of worship; a priest carried a line to the four corner posts of the mana, and the chief sacrificed a pig; name of the line.
song festival, concert.
annual meeting of Sunday Schools, as of Congregationalists.
executive council.
probate court.
general name for court assembly. Names of several types of courts are listed below.
district court.
police court.
circuit court.
old name for ʻaha kākau, court of records.
Supreme Court.
military court, court martial.
superior court.
lower court.
administrative body, assembly.
court of domestic relations.
probate court. Lit., court settling inheritance property.
society, club, association, organization, company, convention. Various types are listed below.
a term used in 1911 for evangelical conference of all the islands.
Christian Endeavor Society.
Temperance union. Lit., society forbidding intoxicating liquor.
academy, learned society.
Hawaiian Sugar Planters' Association.
Sunday School association.
secret society.
Sons and Daughters of Hawaiian Warriors. Lit., warriors' society.
Hawaiian Historical Society.
corporation, association.
congregational.

Word: ʻAhahui Wāhine Kalikiano Hōʻole Wai ʻOna
Definition: Women's Christian Temperance Union.
assembly for ballroom dancing; a ball.
ancient assembly for the hulahula religious ceremony.
bristle worm, a hairy sea creature (Eurythoe complanata).
commemorative wooden or stone pillar (probably short for ʻā hailona, symbolic stone).
• to carry off,    • chase,    • rout;    • to flee, run away.
to go with the wind, to disappear completely.
small gathering for private conversation; small or secret council, as called in an emergency.
short for aha ʻia ana.
drinking party, as:
messenger; to carry word.
Circuit court.
court of records.
a sacred assembly.

sacred sennit cord belonging to a high chief and kept on a high place before his house; trespassers entering the house were killed if the cord remained in place, but if it fell down and the stranger stepped over it, this was a token of the stranger's high rank or kinship with the owner of the cord. Some chiefs had several such cords, each given a name, and some were used after the owner's death in making the kāʻai, container for his bones.
session of the legislature.
an 1854 name for the highest court.
probate court.

native trees (species of Bobea) with small to medium-sized, oblong leaves; small greenish or white flowers; and small, purple-to-black juicy fruits. The wood is yellow and formerly was used for poi boards and canoe rims.
a small-leafed ʻahakea (Bobea elatior var. brevipes).
a large-leafted ʻahakea (Bobea elatior).
senate.
Supreme Court.
grand jury.
lit., powerful court.
cord used for measuring, as in laying out a garden or house.
cabinet, assembly of ministers.
council meeting, discussion meeting, advisory council, conference.
privy council, secret deliberative meeting.
rectangle. lit., two equal sides.
Presbytery, meeting of elders.
judiciary session, meeting of judges.
place or assembly for practice of athletic games, as sham fights. lit., assembly for relaxation.
hammock, as of tapa, fastened to the manuea, center support of a house; hammock in general. lit., sennit meshes.
cord with which edges of cracks in gourd bowls were sewn together in crisscross patterns suggestive of net mesh; the technique for such repair.
strangling in lua fighting, as with green vines.
secret meeting of priests to pray for a chief.
a yellow-spotted needlefish.
concert, song concert, song festival.
an assembly watching a lua contest of the kind called hakakāamoa.
a cord made from the entrails of an enemy killed in a lua fight of the hakakāamoa type.
island conference, with representative from a single island, especially of Congregationalists.
inquisition, inquest.
court of inquiry.

a native sedge (Machaerina mariscoides subsp. meyenii) with pointed, leathery leaves about 90 by 1.6 cm, mostly basal around a more or less zigzag spike, which bears light-brown scattered flower clusters. see also ʻuki, all species of Cladium and Machaerina.
legislature, assembly, council meeting, congress; to hold such meetings; to serve in the legislature.
Legislature, lawmaking body.
Congress of the United States; national assembly.
conference of elders.
Congress.
District court.
convention of delegates from all the islands, especially as held by the Hawaiian Evangelical Association of Congregational Christian Churches.
a kind of tapa dyed with kukui bark and decorated with fine lines, for chiefs.
congregation, prayer assembly.
board of arbitration.
council of chiefs. lit., regal meeting.
waterhead, beginning of a water-course; to overflow.
breeze; to blow or breathe gently. waft; softly blowing.
to exclaim, to oh and ah; yes, so that's it, so, oh.
a hacking cough; to cough. Also ʻehē.
timid, shy, wary.
wild taro. Kauaʻi. Varieties are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula. Called ʻāweu on Hawaiʻi.
soft, gentle in sound.
weak.
to wilt, as a plant; warm, insipid.

a native shrub (Chenopodium oahuense) and an introduced weedy herb (C. album), both with narrow to triangular or rhomboidal, thickish leaves; flowers small, in panicles. Young plants, leaves, and plant tips are used for greens, wrapped in ti leaves and cooked on hot coals. Also ʻahea, ʻāhewahewa, alaweo; alaweo huna (Niʻihau), ʻāweoweo.
var. name for pakai₂, slender amaranth (Amaranthus viridis)...
snare; to snare.

• to condemn, condemnation, 
   • to blame, blame, 
   • to censure, reproach, 
   • to convict; conviction.
wall-eyed, cross-eyed (with maka).
Oʻahu name for the mānā fern.
a mimosa tree.

Hawaiian tuna fishes, especially the yellow-fin tuna (Thunnus albacares), an important fish in the Honolulu market. The name ʻahimay be qualified by the terms hiʻu wīwī (thin tail) or kaʻakaʻalāʻau (dark stripe), kaha uli, kananā (young stage, lit., the defiant one; cf. he aha sananā), kihikihi or ʻōpū hemo (loose belly), lepalepa, maha ʻōʻō (piercing brow), mālailena, maoli, pālaha, and poʻo nui (large head).
faded.
how many?
tinder resulting from plowing with the fire plow; the powdery rubbings that ignite.
to defame, slander, tattle against; false report, defamation, slander.
faint, obscure, faded; dim, as colors in tapa or cloth.
Christmas Eve, Christmas night.
New Year's Eve.
volcano, volcanic fire. lit., fire destroying land.
silvery gray, faded. Niʻihau.
a low spreading bush (Metrosideros sp.), formerly numerous in Nuʻuanu. Also ʻāhihi lehua, lehua ʻāhihi, ʻāhihi kū ma kua.
any plant with long runners or creepers, as cup of gold; any creeping vine.
fireworks (perhaps from Eng. scow [kao], as fireworks were first displayed from ships of explorers).
skyrocket, rocket.
match. lit., scratching fire.
to pass fire from one candlenut to the next on a chain (koli) or candlenut torch. lit., to fire the torch.
seven (especially in counting in a series); seven times.
fire fountain, firebrands thrown over cliffs at Kamaile, Kauaʻi. see ahi and chant, Kauahae.
bits of crustacea and bones found at the opening of an octopus burrow.
gasoline. lit., wind fire.
gray, gray- or white-haired.
blue denim cloth, dungarees, blue jeans.

the silver-sword (Argyroxiphium sandwicense), a native plant found only at altitudes of 1,870 m or more on Maui and Hawaiʻi; the many long silvery leaves forming a rounded rosette to 60 cm in diameter; about a hundred purplish, daisy-like flowers borne on an erect, leafy stem, which is about 1.8 m high.
a native spreading shrub to 1 m high, (Artemisia australis); leaves divided into narrow segments, hoary on under side; flowers in panicles, small, daisy-like. Pounded leaves are used for asthma.
a native fern (Cyrtomium caryotideum), with fronds 25 to 35 cm long, once divided into 6 to 18 broadly sickle-shaped pinnae, lobed at the base.
lazy, indolent; to shirk work, loiter.
albacore, Thunnus alalunga (family Scombridae). lit., flat ʻahi.
match.
pinwheel (fireworks).

• wild, untamed, as animals or plants. 
   • shy, of people (NKE12)
name of a wind common in the mountains of Kahana, Oʻahu and by the sea.
dark, dusky, somber.
line, cord, lashing, fishing line, thong, kite string.
breath; to breathe.
it is better or preferable (used after e, sometimes in comparisons).
thatch purlin. Also ʻaʻaho.
thatch purlin support.
small lashing on the pueo main purlin.
horizontal thatch purlin.
name given for roof thatching on top of the ridgepole.

an endemic fish (Kuhlia sandvicensis) found in both fresh and salt water. The mature stage is āhole, the young stage āholehole. Because of the meaning of hole, to strip away, this fish was used for magic, as to chase away evil spirits and for love magic. It was also called a "sea pig" (puaʻa kai) and used ceremonially as a substitute for pig. Foreigners were sometimes called āhole because of the light skin of the fish.
stroke in lua fighting.
young stage of the āhole, Hawaiian flagtail.
sliding rock, landslide, avalanche.
lit., long-breath.
long line, as with several hooks for deep-sea fishing or for sounding.
better, well, well-being, fortunate, improved; to need (aho₃ + -na).

• patience; patient, 
   • enduring, 
   • long suffering; 
   • to tolerate. 
   • lit., great breath.    
see ex., lawe₂, makua.
lashing fastening kaupaku roof to kua ʻiole, upper ridgepole.
thatch purlin support.
lashing on the pueo main purlin.
main purlin in a house.
young, as of the aku, kawakawa and moano fishes.
healthy, vigorous; strength and vigor, as of animal or plant; to grow rapidly, thrive.
to overeat, waste food, squander.
kukui branches strewn about, as after a storm.
choice mat of fine strands of soft white young pandanus leaves, about 3 cm mesh.
kava dregs.
a sedge (Cyperus javanicus) about .3 to 1.3 m high, with a basal tuft of long narrow leaves and a radiating inflorescence borne at the tip of a long slender stem.
another coarse sedge (Cyperus hypochlorus) similar to the preceding one, but with green instead of brown flowers.
the umbrella plant, a leafless ornamental sedge (Cyperus alternifolius), 30 to 180 cm high, the umbrella-shaped flowering head with about 20 grasslike rays at the top of a slender stalk.
to make two thicknesses by folding; to double up, fold, as paper or tapa.
soft, fine mat garment plaited from fine strands of dried bracts of male pandanus fruit.
bunch or cluster, as of bananas, grapes; whole pandanus fruit consisting of keys.
pandanus fruit.
protuberance of the vagina resulting from syphilis; the roughness of the skin was thought to suggest the pandanus fruit.

to stone to death; slaughter by burying the victim under a pile of stones. Hākau, half brother of ʻUmi, was killed in this fashion (FS 141), and this method was used unsuccessfully against the hero Kawelo (FS 107).
ti-leaf raincoat or cape.

• pestilence, epidemic, 
   • heaped up, as dead bodies.
overheated, as over stones; white-hot.
overdone, overcooked; overcultivated, as soil.
discolored, foamy, feathery, choppy, uneven, mussed.
young of the kūmū fish.
fine patterned mat, plaited with materials of different colors.
pile, heap.
coat, garment, ti-leaf raincoat.
a land division.
a tapa for chiefs, colored with candlenut and noni and striped red.
issue of a union of a male chief and a commoner.
name given for a fish of the ʻōpakapaka type.
matting with twilled pattern, associated with Kauaʻi.
abbreviation for ahupuaʻa₁, land division usually extending from the uplands to the sea...
cloth bound about the head of warriors.

land division usually extending from the uplands to the sea, so called because the boundary was marked by a heap (ahu) of stones surmounted by an image of a pig (puaʻa), or because a pig or other tribute was laid on the altar as tax to the chief. The landlord or owner of an ahupuaʻa might be a konohiki.
the altar on which the pig was laid as payment to the chief for use of the ahupuaʻaland.

old type of raincoat made of dried ti leaves fastened to an olonā net, or consisting of a small mat about 1.2 by 1.8 m, made of makaloa sedge, and so supple that it could be rolled up; to wear this garment. Today, raincoat is kukaweke and kuka ua.
mat canoe covering that protected paddlers in storms.

feather cloak or cape made of the feathers of the ʻōʻō, ʻiʻiwi and other birds, usually red or yellow trimmed with black or green, formerly worn by high chiefs and kings. Today [ca.1957] about 160 have been located in museums and collections of the world, the largest being in the Bishop Museum, Honolulu. Imitation cloaks of plush, felt, paper, or dyed feathers (rare) are worn today in pageants and by members of Hawaiian societies. lit., royal cloak.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the feather cloak.
storehouse, heap of goods.
exposed, conspicuous, prominent, obvious, in plain view; heaped up.
coition; to have sexual relations, cohabit (frequently pronounced ei).
of surprise.
nonproductive transitive suffix. see huaʻi, luaʻi, lumaʻi.
replacing i often in songs; usually written a i.
score, points in a game, stake, wager.
dancing style or type.

• stroke or hold in lua fighting; 
   • spear thrust.
stone used in the kimo game other than the stone that is tossed and caught, which is the pōhaku kimo.
depending on, only if, only when, whatever, whenever.
Here! Here it is!

• ungodly, 
   • godless, 
   •  irreligious, unbelieving, careless of observance of taboos; 
   • wicked, wickedness.
behold! see there! look! suddenly.
same as ʻaiā, ungodly; godless;  irreligious, unbelieving, careless of observance of taboos; wicked, wickedness.

   • fair,

   • brilliant, shining;
a native tree or shrub (Streblus sandwicensis [Pseudomorus sandwicensis and P. brunoniana are synonyms]), with narrow-ovate leaves, and milky sap; a member of the fig family.
dependent, one living on the resources of another.
swinging, unsteady motion.
there, to be there.
down there.
up there.
to rule or own land.
name given for persons sacrificed for not observing taboos during the offering of prayers by the priest (pronunciation not certain).

lit., food of the turtle.
a native trailing, woody plant (Coprosma ernodeoides), with narrow, tiny leaves and black, berry-like fruits. lit., food of the nēnē goose.
There! I told you so! There it is!
to rule (or eat) as a chief.
attendant of the chief's household, intimate of a chief. lit., eating [in the] presence.
to eat like a shark. fig., to have a ravenous appetite.
type of hula with little foot movement, but with hip revolving throughout the dance; to dance thus.
clothes iron; to iron, press, as clothes.
but, furthermore.
to eat like a pig; to eat greedily; to wolf food.
to look about with covetous or jealous eyes; to practice sorcery or poisoning.
weary, discouraged by long continued work.
debt; to owe.

all species of the endemic Hawaiian genus Nothocestrum, soft-wooded shrubs and trees with ovate or oblong leaves, yellowish flowers, and whitish to reddish berries. One slender species was used for thatching sticks (ʻaho) and fire-making.
exhaustion.
hula step danced with bended knees; the chanting for this dance is usually bombastic and emphatic (UL 266); to dance thus. lit., low style.
allegro.
center of a taro corm.

lit., to eat walking.
to eat proudly of high-priced food, as a rich person; fig., to have many women.
vagabond; to wander, roam.
to kidnap; kidnapper.

hard and poor tasting, as thin or inferior fish.

unpounded taro. fig., difficult problem that must be chewed, as whole taro.
name of a star.
lit., man-eating.(HM 241-242). an older cousin of Kawelo; on becoming chief of Kauaʻi he banished Kawelo's parents, thus provoking an invasion. see Kawelo.
an Oʻahu chief who sent men to fetch the beautiful wife of Halemano, causing the couple to flee the island.

a Maui chief who married Hinahānaiakamalama. Hina wearied of disposing of her children's excrement and lept into the moon. Her husband, trying to stop her, caught her leg. She hangs in the moon today.
cannibal, man-eater; to eat human flesh.
friend; friendly; to become a friend.

a privileged friend who shares the profits of a friend's land, sometimes sharing in the work; one who shares a friend's spouse; to share land or spouse; to pay part of a debt but withhold the remainder. lit., eat [on the] border.
to eat under taboo; to observe eating taboos.
sick and tired of a person or situation, surfeited, exhausted, discouraged, fatigued.
to cut or tear obliquely, as with teeth or edged instrument; to seize or tear with the teeth; to fit by rabbeting, rabbet.
to snap the jaws; to speak rapidly, as with overlapping words; to talk too much or too fast; to jabber.

   • to look furtively, peek, peer.
name of a star, possibly Sirius. Also called Hikikauelono (Hiki-kau-e-lono).

interj. of scorn or derision, especially rejoicing over others' misfortunes, with meaning "serves you right" or "I told you so"; as a verb, to use this term.

a bundle of cooked taro wrapped in ti leaves.
gasoline (contraction of ʻaila, oil, and ea, air).

to eat filth (insulting).
to struggle for breath; to breathe with convulsions, gasp, pant, twitch, jerk.
to pull, as weeds.
Irish.
a method of lua fighting; to grab little finger of an adversary and twist it.
away off in the distance.

ceremony usually marking the end of training, so called because the student ate (ʻai) a portion of the head, and especially the brains (lolo), of a fish, dog, or hog offered to the gods; to partake of the ceremony.
skilled, adept, expert, trained, proficient.
up there.
light meal, snack; to eat such.
name of a wind at Hāna, Maui. lit., bait eating.
linnet, California house finch, papaya bird (Carpodacus mexicanus frontalis), an early introduction to Hawaiʻi, now well established throughout the Hawaiian Islands. lit., papaya eater.

exhausted by strain and trouble, tired, weary.
to criticize severely, hunt for flaws, split hairs.
bad temper; bad tempered, cross.
to eat freely, without observance of taboos.

principle or staple food; to eat a lot.
same as ioio, grooves.
a wave that rises and falls without breaking; a swell.
heigh-ho.
slim-necked; a slim or slender neck. Nickname for wives of early missionaries because their bonnets made their necks appear slim.
cooked unpounded taro. lit., whole taro. Kauaʻi.
sagging of the chin and throat, as in old age; double chin; goiter.
stiff neck. fig., disobedience, obstinacy; obstinate.

to eat a dab of bait. fig., to take the leavings of others, to steal another's mate, one who does so; a beggar.
lit., to eat tooth tartar.
glandular swelling in the neck, thyroid.
eater of filth, scavenger; to eat rotten food; rotten food; and insulting epithet for a sorcerer who prays others to death.
to gulp, choke, suffocate.
feast to celebrate the completion of a hard task or project. lit., food [for] workers [in the] sun.
to eat together (both sexes), formerly tabu.
to encircle, go around, encompass, environ.
lumped, calloused, or swollen neck; swelling of the neck or shoulder, said to be caused by carrying heavy burdens; one with a calloused neck.
lumpy poi.
steward, butler, said to be so called because the chief's steward got calluses (puʻupuʻu) on his shoulders from carrying food.
stiff neck. fig., stubborn.
to eat wastefully; a wasteful or riotous eater.
nine (usually in counting in a series); nine times.
nursing, suckling, as an infant; to nurse, suckle; a nursing child, unweaned animal. lit., to eat milk.

the Kauaʻi hero who vainly wooed Lāʻieikawai at the legendary land of Paliuli on Hawaiʻi.(Laie) lit., semidivine chiefly ruler.
abbreviation of ʻākau, north.

carefully, slowly. cf:
         akaʻai to eat slowly, carefully  (ʻai, to eat...)
         akahai modest, gentle...
         akahana to work carefully or slowly (hana, to work...)
         akahao to pick up carefully, as food (hao, to pick up...)
         akahele slow or moderate, cautious... (hele, to go...)

         akaholo to sail or run cautiously (holo, to sail, run...)
         akakuʻu lessened, diminished... (kuʻu, to diminish, as stream water...)
         akalewa to sway the hips daintily... (lewa, to float, swing...)
         akaluli to move slowly, carefully (luli, to shake, sway...)
         akanahe careful, gentle in behavior and speech (nahe, soft, sweet...)
         akanoho to sit quietly, live cautiously (noho, to sit, reside...)
         akaʻōlelo to speak cautiously, deliberately, in moderation (ʻōlelo, to speak...)
shadow. cf. hoaka₄.
embryo at the moment of conception.
newly hatched fish in the stage in which its body is still transparent.
knuckles, as of hands or ankles; joints of the backbone; node and stalk of kava; kava slip for planting.
to laugh; laughter.

• to tear off, peel;    • to break open, as a seal (Hoik. 5.2) ;    • to fall off or down, as old thatching of a house;    • to break up, as the sides of a house;    • to uproot;    • ruffled, as feathers.
a type of fine white tapa.

clear, luminous, transparent, visible, manifest, plain, intelligible; thin, as cloth; shining, bright, distinct.
a white and very thin tapa.
a downy, thorny branching plant (Solanum aculeatissimum), 30 to 90 cm high, from tropical America. It bears round scarlet fruits 2.6 em in diameter, which are strung for leis.
peeled, as the skin by sunburn or by drinking kava; peeling; ruffled. fig., exhausted, thin.

an endemic begonia (Hillebrandia sandwicensis), a succulent herb with oblique, rounded lobed leaves 10 to 20 cm in diameter and with sprays of small pink or white flowers, found only in shaded, damp ravines. Kauaʻi.

the great bulrush (Scirpus validus, formerly called S. lacustris) that grows on the edge of fresh or brackish water marshes in Hawaiʻi. The plants have unbranched, slender, green stems, 1 to 3 m high, looking like giant onion plants. Formerly Hawaiians used them for house thatch or plaited them into mats for the lower layers of beds or for some temporary purposes, as the material is not durable. S. californicus on Niʻihau.
the common onion (Allium cepa); the tops look like those of the great bulrush.
a common variety of onion.
big, yellowish onion. lit., earring onion.
a purplish annual onion.
green onion (Allium fistulosum); its leaves are eaten with salt salmon. lit., leaf onion.
a wild onion, used for sore throat. lit., moon onion, so called because the curve of the section of the bulb suggests a crescent moon.
bulrush.
garlic (Allium sativum).
garlic. lit., bunched onion.
afterglow.
not clear, vague, indistinct.
a variety of seaweed.
a tall endemic climber (Smilax sandwicensis) with tendrils and shiny, leathery, heart-shaped leaves; used for tying rafters.
modest, gentle, unassuming, unpretentious, unobtrusive, docile, decorous, meek, suave; meekness, modesty.
name of a kind of white tapa.
to work carefully or slowly.
to pick up carefully, as food.
to laugh at teasingly, jeer.
one (especially in counting in a series).
for the first time, never before (usually followed by nō).
to have just.
inexperienced, trying out for the first time; novice, beginner.
base of caudal fin.
to paddle carefully, silently.
to sail or run cautiously.
by the sea.
large, potbellied, plump.
to laugh a little, snicker.

spry, quick, nimble, especially about getting into people's way or into trouble.

agate.

negative of a photograph.
destitution, poverty; poor.
the phenomenon known as the Specter of the Brocken, seen at Haleakalā Crater. lit., rainbow apparition.
lessened, diminished, mitigated; to cease, abate, grow calm, stop, as wind, surf, rain, anger, grief, pain; settled, calmed, quieted, appeased.
two endemic raspberries (Rubus hawaiensis and R. macraei); and the thimbleberry (R. rosaefolius), from southeastern Asia.
dye made from ʻākala juice.
a pink tapa.
pinkish.
the ghost or spirit of a living person seen by others, a sign of calamity. lit., many shadows.
string of multicolored glass beads. lit., bead reflections.
to sway the hips daintily, deliberately, and gracefully.
farthing.
to move slowly, carefully.
Assam.
adamant.
Adam.
careful, gentle in behavior and speech.
Arkansas, Arkansan.
to sit quietly, live cautiously.
to speak cautiously, deliberately, in moderation.
stingy, miserly, hard.
Athabasca.
to go here and there, vagabond; vagabond.
red sunset, looked upon as a sign that rain will clear. lit., red shadow.
liver.
to desire, wish, be eager, yearn [the emotions and intelligence were thought to be centered within the body].
to find fault, criticize, slander.

cindery or pebbly soil; cinder.
a honey creeper (Loxops coccinea caeruleirostris). Usually called ʻākepa in Eng.
ruddy turnstone (Arenaria interpres), a winter migrant to Hawaiʻi, occurring in small flocks which rise and wheel together.
to talk loquaciously in a friendly, hospitable manner, bidding a guest to feel at home, make himself comfortable, eat plenty.

Athens.
traveling salesman, commercial traveler.
spleen. lit., coconut-midrib liver.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the liver of Milu
group of small scarlet or yellow-green Hawaiian honey creepers (Loxops coccinea).
quick, nimble, sprightly, active.
liver (more specific than ake). lit., firm liver.

lung.
unkempt, as hair; oblique.
tuberculosis, consumption. lit., finished liver.

endemic shrubs and trees (Wikstroemia spp) with small leaves, tiny yellowish flowers, and yellow to red, small, ovoid one-seeded fruits. The bark yields a fiber; the bark, roots, and leaves (as W. oahuensis) a narcotic used for fish poisoning (Neal 616), and according to Kep., used in ʻanāʻanā sorcery. Varieties are qualified by the terms lau nui, mānalo, and pehu.
Solanum nelsoni. Niʻihau.
to ferment; very sour, as poi.
Asia; Asian, Asiatic.
an endemic, small, hairy, pink-flowered shrub (Hibiscus youngianus), usually found in marshy places.

redup. of ʻaki₁, to take a nip and let go, snap; to nibble, as fish...
   • to nibble, as a fish;
   • constant snapping at, 
   • attacking.
seashore rush grass (Sporobolus virginicus), a coarse grass growing on sandy beaches; used to exorcise spirits.
a kind of coarse red seaweed (Ahnfeltia concinna) which because of its toughness must be eaten in little bites; a good source of carrageenin, a colloid. Called ʻeleau on Maui.

buffalo grass (Stenotaphrum secundatum), an American grass used for lawns. Some people believed that buffalo grass could be used to exorcise spirits because it had been given the same name (ʻakiʻaki) as the seashore rush grass, which was used for this purpose.

a group of Hawaiian honey creepers with long, curved bill, olive or yellow-green above, lighter below (Hemignathus obscurus), with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (H.o.o.), Lānaʻi  (H.o. lanaiesis), and Kauaʻi  (H. procerus). The latter is endangered; it has the longest curved beak, for sipping honey at the base of ʻieʻie and hala pepe leaves. cf. ʻiwi, ʻiʻiwi.
Asia Minor.

a small black sea bird, probably a stormy petrel (Oceanodroma), of which two dark, sooty species are known about the Hawaiian Islands, especially those to the northwest. lit., billow-treading ʻakihi.
a bird listed by Malo.

drydock, lit., floating canoe-rest.
dip net, as used in fishing uhu.
acid.
carbolic acid.
dwarfed; dwarf.
the endemic Kauaʻi creeper (Loxops maculata bairdi, formerly Paroreomyza bairdi).
Adriatic.

a wrasse fish of the hīnālea type (Gomphosus varius). Also  hīnālea ʻakilolo. This fish was used by priests as the pani or closing medicine for head diseases. The taro or sugar cane of the same name might substitute. lit., brain biting.
a variety of sugar cane, striped with green and deep purplish-red when young, with yellow and red when older; named for the fish.
a variety of taro.
a variety of sugar cane, with purplish leaves.
Adirondack.
to take with a lou or fruit-plucking stick.
feast of unleavened bread.
admiral.
biting; bite.

crest of a wave; to break or swell, as waves.

mushroom coral (Fungi scutaria). lit., vagina coral.
the crested honey creeper (Palmeria dolei), formerly endemic on Maui, endangered.

endemic shrubs and trees (Euphorbia spp.) with jointed stems, opposite leaves, and milky sap. Buds and leaves of one species (E. multiformis) were chewed for debility.
bloody.
Azores.
poor, destitute, shiftless.
a large endemic fern (Dryopteris unidentata), 1 m or more high, with triangular-oblong fronds much subdivided.
a native fern (Athyrium microphyllum syn. A. poiretianum) with beautiful, large, lacy fronds.
a small mollusk (Epitonium perplexum). Often called pipipi ʻākōlea or kōlea.
accordion.
ostrich.
to creep, attempt to creep; to put out small roots, as potatoes.
three (as in counting in a series); three times.
atomic.
adobe.
an endemic lobelia (Cyanea tritomantha), a small tree 2 to 3 m high, with clustered leaves (up to 78 by 20 cm), somewhat downy beneath. The leaves were cooked and eaten like cabbage.
God (Christian).
"it" in a game of tag or hide-and-seek.
name of the 14th night of the full moon.
spirit eater of scraps, designation of a god sent on errands of destruction by sorcerers.
a spirit that destroys its keeper; a god sent on an evil errand who returns to destroy his keeper rather than the victim; any evil practice, as excessive drinking, gossiping.
spirit eater of filth. same as akua ʻai hamu.
supernatural with dual roles as akua to unrelated persons and ʻaumakua to relatives, as formerly the four major gods to high ranking chiefs, and later only as Pele, Hiʻiaka, and Laka to mortals.
a god to whom one appealed with offerings for help, as in fishing, farming, or killing an enemy. lit.. work god.
spirits, as of a recently dead kinsman, who were fed (hānai) offerings (such as food) and sent out to destroy an enemy.

the kauila, nīoi₂, and ʻohe "poison" woods of Molokaʻi, which were kept by sorcerers in their houses, wrapped in tapa, and to which food offerings were made daily; scraps of these woods were used as poison, and poison itself was sometimes called akua hānai.
god sent on errands of destruction.
feather image.

stick image (general name); image wrapped in tapa; image consisting of a carved staff, with a tuft of feathers at the top, bound to its bearer by a sash (kāʻai₁) (Malo 80) and carried into battle; staff with a carved figure at the head, used in ceremonies to procure offspring.
Holy Trinity.
a god to whom offerings and sacrifices were made.
image representing a god.
swaying, as a canoe in rough sea; not steady; bumpy, as a road.
hasty, poorly done, rash.
an endemic lobelia (Cyanea rollandioides) 1 to 1.4 m high, with rough leaves to 50 by 15 cm. The leaves were cooked like cabbage or taro tops or sweet potato leaves, with pork or salt beef.

similar to akua hānai₁,spirits sent out to destroy an enemy...; akua hānai₂,  scraps of woods used as poison...;  sent out in the shape of fireballs to kill, or inserted in a victim's food, water, or tobacco.
ghost, specter, apparition, evil spirit.
flying god, usually a poison god sent to destroy, sometimes in the form of fireballs (pōpō ahi).

a tall image, especially an image of Lono carried on a circuit of the island during the makahiki, harvest festival; it was called loa, long, because of its "long" travels. The image consisted of a staff about two fathoms long. Pieces of pala fern, feather leis, and skins of the kaʻupu bird were fastened to a crosspiece tied near the top of the staff, in the center of which was a tiny carved head. A long and white tapa banner was attached to the crosspiece. ((Malo 143–5), but see (Malo text, chapter 36, sections 22–4)) Tribute was collected. also Lono Makua.
foreign god, epithet often applied to Pele because she had come from a foreign land.
a spirit that takes possession of people and speaks through them as a medium.
image representing the god of sports that accompanied the akua loa on its circuit, to preside at the sport festivals.
the god of nightmares; a god who carried persons to distant places in their sleep, especially if they had eaten certain fish, as the weke.
last and slow-moving image in a procession during kauila nui ceremonies.

similar to akua loa (a tall image, especially an image of Lono carried on a circuit of the island during the makahiki), except that it was taken to a poko₃ (a small division of a district, sometimes the personal lands of a chief)
a god that inspires or possesses people.
goddess.
club-footed; deformity of the feet.
to pound.
to pound.
a long fish net; to drive fish into the net by striking the water with sticks.
adjutant.
adjutant general.
to beat, as tapa.
tossing about, agitated; jolting, as a vehicle on a rough road.
aku + demon. lā.
big-eyed or goggle-eyed scad fish (Trachurops crumenophthalmus), Stages of growth are pāʻāʻā, halalū or hahalalū, and akule.
to give property or a right to it; to delegate responsibility.
adultery.
to collect, as leaves in a stream; to dam a stream thus; forest pool where leaves and rubbish have accumulated. fig., to cast a reflection.
Assyria.
general name for succulent plants.

a coastal herb (Sesuvium portulacastrum), known in many warm regions, somewhat like wild portulaca (ʻākulikuli kula), but with longer, narrower leaves, and with small white to magenta flowers at leaf axils.
Portulaca cyanosperma. Niʻihau.
a tropical American, low succulent (Batis maritima), commonly forming a continuous green cover by salt marshes. Locally called pickleweed.
purslane (Portulaca oleracea), a cosmopolitan weed, a small succulent, prostrate herb, with spatula-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. It is eaten by people, poultry, and stock. lit., plain succulent.
ice plant (Lampranthus glomeratus) from Africa, a low succulent, with thick, narrow leaves, and pink, rose, or orange flowers (used for leis).
broken or cut off, as a pencil point; blunt, stumpy.
a while ago, last.
a small endemic tree (Bobea mannii).

fast, quickly. cf.
     alaheo, gone, departed   (heo depart in haste)
      alamimo, quick, fast   (mimo deft...)
     alapine₁, quick, fast   (pinepine often)
     alawiki, to hurry; quick, fast   (wiki quick)
to rise up, arise, get up, come forward.
there (same as the more frequent lā and -la). cf. e lākou ala, e lauala, e (verb) ala.
a variety of taro, said to be pungent-smelling when cooked. Varieties are qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, ʻōpelu; cf. also ʻalaopuna.

dense waterworn volcanic stone, as used for poi pounders, adzes, hula stones; hard lava, basalt. Kinds of ʻalā rock, as used for adzes, are qualified by the phrases pia maka hinu, shiny-faced arrowroot; māhinu, shiny; and maka hinu, shiny face. also (Kam. 76:122) ʻalā haumeku ʻolokele, ʻalā lelekepue.

a large endemic tree (Planchonella spp.) with smooth, oblong leaves, shiny-green above, bronze beneath, the fruit yellow or black, to 5 cm long. The sticky, milky sap was used to trap birds, the wood for spears and ʻōʻō handles.
ʻŌʻō digging stick made of ʻālaʻa or any wood; to prod or dig with a stick, as in taro cultivation. Fig., to dig into the mind; to be dislodged, as by the wind.
small corm, as of taro.
a strong Hilowind. lit. land-prodding.
scar of a scrofulous sore; to be so scarred; perhaps tuberculosis adenitis.
aerial tubers of bitter yam, hoi (Dioscorea bulbifera).
small ʻalā stones.
small tubers, as of taro.
lukewarm; half-cooked
type of taro patch built on artificial mounds, known near Hiloas kipi; mucky claylike soil, as in this type of patch.
all species of Peperomia, small native succulent forest herbs, related to ʻawa. The name is qualified by the terms kāne (on Oʻahu) or kupa liʻi (on Hawaiʻi), pehu, pōhina.
a small weedy herb (Plectranthus parviflorus), in the mint family. This name may be qualified by the terms pua kī, wahine.
to tell publicly, as of the past
type of ancient dramatic hula.
long cloud formation.
river ford; place on a trail where one swims or wades across a stream.
a West Indian shrub, night cestrum (Cestrum nocturnum), Chinese inkberry, with narrow leaves and narrow, tubular, green-to-creamy white flowers, which are most fragrant at night.

mudhen or Hawaiian gallinule (Gallinula chloropus sandvicensis), a black wading bird with red frontal plate; cry of this bird is believed a bad omen; some considered the ʻalae an ʻaumakua; endangered. For the coot, see ʻalae kea. see saying, keʻu.

• water-soluble colloidal ocherous earth, used for coloring salt, for medicine, for dye, and formaly in the purification ceremony called hiʻuwai; 
   • any red colloring matter;    • according to Dr. Frank Tabrah, brick-red soil containing hematite.
flesh like redness, especially the dark red meat close to the spine of some fish, as of the aku.

annatto dye plant (Bixa orellana), a tropical American shrub or small tree, bearing fruit with scarlet seeds, used for dyeing. Sometimes called ʻalaea lāʻau to distinguish from the earth; locally also called lipstick plant.

• tribe or clan; 
   • people in a district who have intermarried.
bad breath, halitosis.
fore part of thigh; long narrow thigh muscle.
dark-red ʻalaea. lit., male ʻalaea₃.
light-red ʻalaea. lit., female ʻalaea₃.
the introduced Australian gallinule Porphyrio poliocephalus, P. p. melanotus. Also applied to a form of ʻalae kea, with brownish frontal knob.
an edible crab of the Portunus sp., sandcolored, and found in shallow water.
Hawaiian coot (Fulica americana alai), a marsh and pond bird, distinguished from ʻalae ʻula by its ivory-white frontal knob; endangered.
a wind of Mānoa Valley, Honolulu.
lit., white-beaked ʻalae.
Hawaiian gallinule or mudhen (Gallinula chloropus sandvicensis), distinguished from ʻalae kea by its reddish bill and frontal plate; endangered.

• plank bridge, 
   • rough road over ravines or chasms, 
   • trestle, 
   • ladder.
type of braid used in the pāpale ʻie.
mountain ladder or steps cut into a cliff.
railway, railroad track. lit., iron road.

a large native shrub or small tree (Canthium odoratum; synonym Plectronia odorata) with shiny leaves and small, fragrant, white flowers. The wood is hard and was formerly used in making the ʻōʻō digging stick; also used medically.
mock orange (Murraya paniculata), an ornamental hedge plant with shiny, dark-green leaves, small fragrant white flowers, and red berries.
pedestrian's road, sidewalk.
gone, departed.
hem or finished border of a plaited mat or hat.
wooden bridge.
to wake up early for no reason
name of a light Hilo breeze. lit., land fragrance. Also ʻAʻalahonua.
name of a Molokaʻi wind.
resurrection; to rise again, resurect.
marine railway. lit., road to pull ships.

• a frequented and well-known path; to frequent such; 
   • to tread or trample, as on a taboo being broken. And.
obstruction, hindrance, block, bar, screen; to obstruct, hinder, block, defend, stand in the way, oppose, hamper.
two sticks carried with the akua loa in the makahiki festival; they were used to mark the boundry of the taboo area.
gentle, as a breeze.
small thin surfboard, as of breadfruit or koa wood, and heavier than the olo board.
an upland bird, gray, about rite size of the ʻelepaio, reported in 1863.

various species of squirrelfishes of the family Holocentridae, including Flammeo sammara (spotfin squirrelfish, 185 mm), Adioryx lacteoguttatus (whitespotted, 117 mm), A. diadema, (crown, 109 mm), A. xanterythrus (Hawaiian, 132 mm), A. tiers (Tahitian, 259 mm). The young are called ʻaʻalaʻihi. Unidentified kinds are qualified by the terms ākoʻakoʻa, kala loa or kanaloa, lā kea, māhū, maoli, and pilikoʻa.
pale pink tapa; any faded color
a variety of sugar cane named for the fish, either a deep-red mutant of ʻāwela or related to it; internodes barrel-shaped, leaves purple.
appropriation of property by force, as practiced by some chiefs on their travels; to do so
obstacle, obstruction.
Alaska.
sea course, path where one must swim past a projecting cliff.
potbellied, bloated.
leadership, guidance.
detour.
allspice.
to jump, hurry from place to place.
name of a star, probably used in navigation.
name of a downtown Honolulu street. lit., white road.
Alaska.
Arden.
arsenic.
to drag, pull along.
bird-catching pole.
Aragon.
a large crab (Carpilius maculatus), with 11 dark red spots on its back, usually found concealed in rocks or under stones.
place for climbing a cliff, usually with ropes.
sweet potatoes that bear front branch (lālā) vines.
to bawl, bleat, squeal, cry, caw, yelp, wail, scream; such noises.
Hawaiian crow (Corvus tropicus), named for its caw; endangered [extinct in the wild].
a style of chanting with open mouth vibration and tremor of the voice, and prolonged vowels; to chant thus
to gargle.
Ararat.
to dry or wither leaves over a fire, as of tobacco.
bleating, wailing.
young of the red ʻāweoweo fish. Appearance of schools of this fish near shore was an omen that royalty would die.
sickly, weak, fretful, as a child; fretfulness.
sharp shrill yelp, sudden screech; to yelp, screech.
protection, defense.
bowling alley
ripe
precious, as a child
a bird (no data)
hard volcanic stone, used for adzes
a common black crab (Metopograpsus thukuhar).
quick, fast.
an endemic fresh-water ʻoʻopu fish (Len tipes concolor). Hilo. Also hiʻu ʻula, hiʻu kole.
cut off or unfinished road, dead-end road. fig., an incomplete rainbow, rainbow fragment
awakening, rising.
offering, especially a free-will offering, contrasting with a mōhai that was prescribed by a priest; to offer.
light, buoyant, easily floating.
peace offering, offering of love.
burnt offering, offering to procure death by sorcery.
of a single color or texture, especially of a feather cloak without design and made of feathers of a single kind and color.
swelling disease, dropsy, generalized edema, kidney disease.

name of a class of 12 male supernatural beings called papa pae māhū, said to be hermaphrodite healers from Kahiki. One at least was according to legend turned to stone and has been moved to Kuhiō Park, Waīkīkī, Oʻahu. see Paemāhū (in Pukui, Elbert and Mookini, 1974).

brown seaweeds (Dictyota spp.), regularly divided into narrow segments. They are so bitter that they will taint other seaweeds put with them and can be eaten but little and by some are considered poisonous. Medical kahunas used them in small quantities to treat asthma. This name is sometimes qualified by the terms kai and ʻula. Also maka and false līpoa.

an Oʻahu tree (Pelea sandwicensis or P. oahuensis), with oblong, fragrant leaves (like the mokihana of Kauaʻi), which were used for scenting tapa. The bark was used for medicine. Also other species of Pelea.
an upland moss.
smooth, even, not rough.
calamondin (Citris mitis), a small tree with flattened-globose fruits to 2.6 cm in diameter, orange-colored, few-seeded, sour.
long tattoo stripe. lit., tooth path.
all species of Pelea.

tangerine, mandarin (Citrus reticulata cv. ‘deliciosa’), a small tree with small leaves and small, loose-skinned, orange, flattened globose, sweet fruits. lit., Chinese orange. On Niʻihau, identified as C. grandis; cf. (Neal 481).
a low native shrub (Pelea waialealae), found only on high, wet parts of Kauaʻi.
avenue, boulevard, wide street.
sidewalk.
pathway of the navigator stars; star course followed by navigators. Probably also hōkū ʻai ʻāina.
to swallow whole, as a fish or shrimp.
Heiau or temple that had no lele altar.
road cut, short cut.
name of a Kauaʻi wind, said to bring good weather. lit., happy path.
narrow path, lane, alley.
a variety of taro, growing wild, also cultivated dry in Puna, Hawaiʻi; fragrant when cooked, like kāī.
athletic, active; athlete; an epithet for Kamehameha I; name of a company of Kalaniʻopuʻu's warriors.
slander, falsehood, deceit; slanderer; to slander, defame, deceive, lie.
alpaca.
alabaster, ointment vase of alabaster.
Albany.
tunnel.
alfalfa.
athletic person aspiring to the lineage of Kū (said of Kamehameha).
Arabia, Arabian.
a heavy cloth resembling serge.
stairs, steps, ladder, stile, doorstep, ascent, scale (musical).
lua fighting stroke. lit., stairway of the shrimp.
steep road or path.
escalator, moving stairs.
musical scale.
belly of a fish, considered choice.
quick, fast.
frequent, often.
night awakening.
orbit of the stars, circular road.
to gulp, swallow whole.
shipwrecked.
name of a dark basalt.
body sores; to have such sores; affected with dry rot, as taro.
small, young, of creatures.
dividing, branching, as of winds and lineages.

• homely, homeliness,
   • vile, vileness, 
   • slovenly, 
   • worthless;  
   • dregs of society.
light of early dawn, sunset glow. lit., flaming road.
red dust in a road, red dust.
clothes, tapa, mats; to envelop, clothe.
sheer trail as for climbing a cliff.
to draw, pull, attract, as a magnet.
to glance, look quickly; glance.
a bird (no data).
canoe course.
road, highway. lit., cleared road.
channel, canal.
dark lines on stomach of a pregnant woman, converging near the navel. lit., burned path.
to shriek; shrill.
upland bird, reported to be the young of the ʻanianiau, and on Kauaʻi, the ʻamakihi.
to hurry; quick, fast.
to swallow, engulf, gulp, absorb.
hollow or cavern on the sea floor.
an endemic mountain plant (Plantago princeps), 60 cm to 2 m high, rarely branching, stem woody, with long narrow leaves at top; related to the laukahi.
gust.
are, a unit of measure.
marshy; marsh, swamp.
a fish, said to be short for hīnālea, or a kind of hīnālea.
sweet-voiced.
area.
a swamping wave, as one striking a canoe broadside from prow to stern.
wounded, pierced; wound, sore. Less common than pōaleale.
a shellfish (Turbo sandwicensis); its shell.
snare, noose; to snare.
ashes.
large tree of the pine family, cedar, fir. (Bib.)
Alexandria.
Arkansas.
Allegheny.
arsenic.
heron.
alto.
alcohol.
whitecaps, white spray.
long-backed billow.
algum tree. (Bib.)
dashing billow.
to skip, jump, fly.
tongue, language. Also elelo.
meat of the sea egg or sea urchin (wana), so called because of resemblance to a tongue.
concave curve of the lower portion of the lei palaoa, whale-tooth pendant, suggestive of a tongue.
point at the tip of a paddle.
a kind of introduced flower (no data).
coated tongue.
tongue-tied, paralyzed tongue.
paralysis of the tongue, believed sometimes caused by a kahuna. Also alelo pehu, alelo pelu, lelo puʻu
Alma Mater.
almanac, calendar.
Armenia; Armenian.
almond (Prunus dulcis), hazel tree (KJV), almond (RSV) (Kin. 30.37) .
a lowland perennial weed (Boerhaavia repens), with long, thin, prostrate branches, bearing small leaves and flowers. The swollen roots were used medicinally, acting as a diuretic. Anena on Niʻihau.
tower, high lookout, gazebo; towering.
billows that follow one after the other.
alpha.
alphabet.
Albuquerque.
old, worn-out, as tapa, mats, clothing; worn-out tapa, clothing; objects of inferior quality.
buoyant, floating.
(perhaps a var. of ani.)
scar, depression, groove, imbedded mark. Also ʻeli.
to wait, stop; before; usually as a command: Stop! Wait a minute!
salt bed, salt-encrusted area; salty, brackish.

name of two kauila or māmane sticks carried by priests before the makahiki god; also the two crossed spears with upright spear in the center, used as insignia for the present-day Māmakakaua society; small flag or streamer.
crystal clear, white; clarity, whiteness.

cords or fine ropes threaded through marginal meshes of upper and lower edges of nets, to which were attached floats and sinkers; loops at the top of a kōkō net holding a calabash. see below and ʻupena ʻalihi.
horizon (sometimes qualified by lani or moana). cf. lihi, edge.
deceit, trickery; to deceive, cheat.
general, commander in battle, strategist.
commander in chief.
lower cord in a net to which lead sinkers were attached.
dragnet, mullet net.
line for lashing down the pāʻū mat covering of a canoe.
upper cord in a net to which floats were attached.
lower cord in a net to which stone sinkers were attached.
chief who rules a moku (district).
Archangel.
presiding officer, ruling officer; chairman, viceroy.
male chief, king; husband (polite, not said of one's own husband or to him).
military officer, officer of army or navy.
commissioned officer.
warrant officer.
power behind the throne. lit., supplementary king.
independent chief, aristocrat.
true chief, commissioned officer (old term).
same as Kealiʻiokonaikalewa.
non-commissioned officer, petty officer (old term).
offspring of a high chiefess and commoner (or lesser chief) father.

the ornamental cannas (Canna indica, forms and hybrids), large tropical American herbs, with large oval or narrow leaves and large red or red and yellow flowers. The round black seeds are worn in leis and are also placed in fruit shells of the laʻamia for hula rattles. Cannas are both cultivated and wild in Hawaiʻi.
lesser chiefs who served other chiefs.
an exalted chief (probably from pūʻoʻa, tower).
boatswain.
chiefess, queen; wife (polite, not said of one's own wife or to her).
Arctic.
clammy, sticky, tenacious, tough. fig., stingy.
alike (often repeated): ʻālike ʻālike, like ʻālike, alike, just alike, identical, equally, midway.
alligator.
to tighten, tie tightly.
the common turbo shell (Turbo sandwicensis).
five (especially in counting in a series); five times.
arithmetic.

   • fig., low, disgraced, degraded, dishonored.
limpet (Cellana sandwicensis).

   • come near, 
   • go with, attend, escort, accompany, 
   • endure,
   • resist.
name recorded for olonā fiber.
to lengthen, enlarge.
in the presence of chiefs; royal court.
squilla (Pseudosquilla ciliata, Lysiosquilla maculata), highly desired as food. Also Squilla sp.
loved and served by many persons, as a chief or favorite child; esteemed.
tapa made from māmaki mixed with wauke.
lumpy, as poi.
a kind of small inshore fish (no data).
far, at a distance.
pitted, as rocks.
aloe, any plant of the genus Aloe; also the pānini ʻawaʻawa.

love of the land or of one's country, patriotism; the name of a Hawaiian-language newspaper published 1893–1920; aloha ʻāina is a very old concept, to judge from the many sayings (perhaps thousands) illustrating deep love of the land. (Aloha ʻāina) in (PN 268–9) cf. the song Kaulana nā Pua (EM 62–4).
brotherhood.
Bible spelling of aloha ai.
good morning...
(less used than hoʻālohaloha).
name given to the kāmole plant used in hana aloha sorcery. lit., mutual love.
may you be loved or greeted, greetings (to one person).
pitiless, merciless, ungrateful, without love or affection.
to shine, glitter, sparkle; bright, brilliant; splendor, brilliancy.
families united by marriage, in-laws.
brightness of heaven, a term applied to the heavenly courts of the goddesses Uli and Kapo.
radiant.
mud puddle, pool.
a damselfish (Dascyllus albisella). The young stage is ʻā or ʻaʻā.
humble.
single weft in plaiting; mat of a single thickness, with only one shiny side. lit., single side.
attractive, of fine appearance.
a red bird reported by Kepelino (no data).
alodial title, alodium, fee simple.
two-sided, two-faced; facing one another, as cliffs on opposite sides of a valley.
double weft in plaiting; plaiting with a reversible side, with two thicknesses.
aroma.
shiftless, dependent on others for a livelihood.
fox.
persons shouting, as in mourning.
belly of a fish, choice to Hawaiians.
combined, acting together; to cooperate, act together.
two, twice. Pōʻalua, Tuesday; lit., second day.
old, worn-out, faded, dilapidated; old and wrinkled, as a person.

• to follow, pursue, chase; 
   • to run, as for political office.
rough, bumpy, as a road; full of knotholes, as a board; pitted with holes, as a reef.
multiplication tables.
loose, as a bundle not securely tied; flabby, ill-fitting, loose-jointed.
crowd, heap; mixed, crowded, heaped.
to destroy; destructive.

an endemic member of the lobelia family (Brighamia spp.), presently known only on Molokaʻi and Kauaʻi, believed extinct on Maui and Niʻihau, an unbranched, succulent, thick-stemmed perennial about 1.5 m high, topped with a rosette of large oval leaves and racemes of long, white, fragrant flowers. also hāhā.
to incline the head, sway.
work together...
quickly, hastily (used after hele, hana, holo, holoholo, hopuhopu).
descent, loosening, slackening, stooping.
late afternoon or early evening.
early afternoon.
greedy, covetous, rapacious; greed, greedy person.
outrigger float; port hull of a double canoe, so called because it replaces the float.
talkative, prattling, tattling.
light, bright.
young ʻamaʻama fish, usually called pua ʻama.

mullet (Mugil cephalus), a very choice indigenous fish. Stages are (finger length) pua ʻama, pua ʻamaʻama, pua poʻolā, ʻoʻolā; (hand length) kahaha (or pahaha); (20 cm) ʻamaʻama; (30 cm or more) ʻanae. fig., an easy mark (modern slang).
in rapid succession.
to cause death, defeat.

a group of small endemic Hawaiian honey creepers, Loxops virens; abundant on Hawaiʻi (L. v. v.), Maui (L. v. wilsoni), and Kauaʻi, uncommon on Oʻahu (L. v. chloris) and Molokaʻi, rare on Lānaʻi. The feathers are yellow and greenish, and were formerly used in feather capes. The Kauaʻi form was also called alawī kihi.
armorer, blacksmith.
finished, of a pre-Christian prayer (said almost at the end of a prayer); to finish a prayer, to pray and sacrifice.

all species of an endemic genus of ferns (Sadleria), with trunk more or less evident. The fronds are narrower, smaller, and less divided than those of the hāpuʻu. At least one species has at the top of the trunk a mass of soft scales (pulu) used as pillow stuffing. Formerly, in times of famine, the tasteless pith of the trunk was cooked and eaten. The fronds were used to mulch dry-land taro, the stems for plaiting and as sizing for tapa. The ʻamaʻu was one of the forms that Kamapuaʻa, the pig god, could take at will. Also maʻumaʻu, maʻu.
place where ʻamaʻu₁ ferns are found.

Oʻahu thrush (Phaeornis obscurus oahuensis), dusky, olive-brown above, ashy-gray beneath, endemic, presumed extinct, with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (ʻōmaʻo₃), Lānaʻi (olomaʻo), Molokaʻi (olomaʻo), and Kauaʻi.
young ʻamaʻu ferns; many ʻamaʻu ferns, ferny, abounding in ʻamaʻu ferns; a covering of ʻamaʻu ferns (preceded by ke).
and (sometimes written ame).
Amherst.
Amsterdam.
amethyst.
amethyst. (Puk. 28.19)
America; American.
North America, North American.
South America, South American.
United States of America.
United States of America, American.
Central America, Central American.
amen; to say amen.
amber.
hinge, joint; to turn on hinges.
a hula step with hip revolutions; to do this step. Three types are ʻami kāhela, ʻami kūkū, and ʻami ʻōniu.
measuring worm.
exaggerated and rapid revolving of the hips in the hula; to do so.
joint. lit., connecting joint.
ball-and-socket joint. lit., swinging connecting joint.
hula step; hip rotations with weight on the right hip as the left heel lifts very slightly, then reversing; to do this ʻami.
an amphipod (Caprellid amphipods) that clings to seaweeds or hydroids; it has a long slender body and is the color of the seaweed or hydroid on which it feeds.
a relish, morsel, or bit of food, scraps of food.

a hula step with ʻami; like the ʻami kāhela except that the revolutions are smaller and faster and in groups of three; sometimes two slower kāhela revolutions are followed by three faster kūkū revolutions; to perform this step.
very rapid revolution of the hips in the hula; an uninhibited (kuʻupau) ʻami; to do so.
name recorded for a type of lava rock on Lehua Island. Niʻihau.
the figure-eight hula step; the revolving hips (ʻami) form an eight, with weight shifting; to perform this step. lit., spinning ʻami.
an ʻami hula step with abdomen thrust forward, considered in poor taste; to do this step. lit. stomach ʻami.
same as ʻami kāhela but a new term. lit., round ʻami.
hinge of door or gate.
to carry a burden on the shoulders, to lift weights; a burden. fig., responsibility.
wink, sparkle; to wink, sparkle, glimmer, twinkle.
contraction of the anal muscles, anal opening, vagina. cf. pī ka ʻamo under pī₂.
to raise or mount high, as waves; high, raised.
a stick for carrying burdens on the shoulder.
irregular, uneven.

Hawaiian soap plant (Colubrina asiatica), a twining shrub, distributed from Africa, India, and Australia to Polynesia, with ovate- to heart-shaped leaves and small round fruits. large taro-like plants (Alocasia macrorrhiza, Xanthosoma robustum). A number of beliefs concerning ʻape have been recorded. ʻape was planted by a gate or fence because the irritating sap of the leaves was thought to ward off evil spirits; leaves were placed under tapas or mats on which the sick lay for the same reason. ʻape was not planted near the house for fear the residents might become sick. Varieties are qualified by the colors kea or keʻokeʻo (white), or hiwa or ʻeleʻele (dark).

some representatives of an endemic genus (Isodendrion), members of the violet family. They are small shrubs beating greenish-white or reddish flowers, which have equal petals and none spurred.

everything, as of things taken or lost; destitute.

milkfish (Chanos chanos). Stages of growth are pua awa (puawa), young; awa ʻaua, medium size; awa, commercial size; awa kalamoho, very large.
noisy, loud; to talk loudly.

the kava (Piper methysticum), a shrub 1.2 to 3.5 m tall with green jointed stems and heart-shaped leaves, native to Pacific islands, the root being the source of a narcotic drink of the same name used in ceremonies (Neal 291), prepared formerly by chewing, later by pounding. The comminuted particles were mixed with water and strained, When drunk to excess it caused drowsiness and, rarely, scaliness of the skin and bloodshot eyes. Kava was also used medicinally.
sour, bitter, poisonous.
cold mountain rain, fog, mist; to rain or mist. fig., tragic misfortune or ordeal; in (PH) this word is preceded by ke and may refer to volcanic eruption:
a premature infant, believed caused by a "sour" condition of the mother.
a kind of bitter seaweed.
long, narrow excavation, trench, ditch, gully; to dig a ditch or furrow.
it is said that the god Kāne brought the first ʻawa to Hawaiʻi.
a variety of kava with long, light-green internodes and reddish nodes.
a variety of kava.
a herring-like fish, sometimes called tenpounder or tarpon (Elops hawaiensis); according to some, a medium-sized awa fish.

uneven, furrowed, craggy.
muscular.

good spirits, as the messengers of Kāne, who guarded people from evil ghosts and managed the rain, winds, and weather.
kava root dug ceremonially by a priest and held up (kū) towards heaven while chanting a prayer of consecration and eulogy, after which the root was termed ʻawailani.
a large awa, milkfish.
probably same as ʻawa papa kea.
a variety of kava with green internodes of medium length.
ship harbor or anchorage, port.
avoirdupois.

• to pull back steadily, as a line.

many channels
a young kava plant (root, stem, and leaves) used as an offering to the gods.
to burn for no particular reason; susceptible to combustion; spontaneous combustion; overcooked.
type of hard stone from which adzes were made.
place where bones of chiefs were hidden, as in a cave, lit., eternal harbor.
eight (usually in counting in a series).
name for ʻawa ākea, ʻawa mākea at Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
a variety of kava.
a variety of kava with short internodes and light-green stalk, reported at Wainiha, Kauaʻi.
a variety of kava with smooth, white stalk.
a variety of kava with short, dark-green internodes and whitish nodes, called ʻawa papa mōʻī at Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
a variety of kava with short yellowish-green internodes and hairlike roots, named for the mokihana plant because of its fragrance, and yielding a strong brew; famous on Kauaʻi.
a variety of kava with long, spotted internodes.

a variety of kava with short internodes and spotted stalk. This name may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, mōʻī, and kea (or keʻokeʻo), the last being the commonest variety, and whitish in general appearance.
a variety of sweet potato.
a type of taro (no data).
lit., edible ginger.
Liparis hawaiensis, a small, endemic orchid with two large ovate leaves and small flowers.
the white ginger (Hedychium coronarium), a large herb from India, both wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi. White fragrant flowers, popular for leis and perfume, are borne in heads at tips of leafy stems.

torch ginger (Phaeomeria speciosa), a large herb, from the East Indies, grown in Hawaiʻi for its ornamental pink or red cone-shaped flower heads. These are borne on long stems separate from the longer leafy stems.  lit., walking-stick ginger.
wild ginger

the shell ginger (Catimbium speciosum), a large ornamental herb from East Indies. Clusters of irregularly bell-shaped flowers that are white and marked with red and yellow bend downward from the top of leafy, arching stems, which are 1.5 to 3.5 m high. lit., drooping ginger.
the yellow ginger (Hedychium flavescens), similar to ʻawapuhi keʻokeʻo and similarly used, but the flowers are yellow.
ginger (Zingiber officinale), yielding a valuable commercial root spice. The plant looks much like ʻawapuhi kuahiwi and probably comes from southeast Asia.  lit., Chinese ginger.
the red ginger (Alpinia purpurata), an ornamental plant having a long flower spike with many red bracts. It is a native of some islands of the western Pacific.
valley, gulch, ravine.
a variety of kava, an offshoot of ʻawa hiwa, with joints green on one side and dark on the other.  lit., watery kava of the bird.
wake of a ship.
pack, knapsack carried on the back; to carry on the back.
tentacle.

• tenacious, 
   • sticky, adhesive; glueyness,
   • threadlike,  threads.
wake, as of a ship.

goal, mark, line, goal post.
average, pro rata. divided equally.

various Hawaiian species of Priacanthus, red fishes, sometimes called bigeye. Young are called ʻalalauā and ʻalauwā.

same as ʻāheahea₂, a native shrub (Chenopodium oahuense).
a seaweed.
eel tentacle, but referring to the octopus, a euphemism for ʻaweule.
a native variety of taro, often growing wild; good for poi, but too acrid for table taro; the corms are shaggy and fibrous outside, the flesh white with yellow fibers.
lone octopus tentacle, said to wave in order to entice and ensnare a victim. lit., penis tentacle.
to wink, ogle. see saying, lihilihi₂.
to hurry, be quick, swift.
a vine (Canavalia spp.), native to Hawaiʻi, related to the maunaloa (C. cathartica), but with narrower pods; used for small, temporary fish traps.
to mix, interweave, entwine; mixed, agitated.
alligation (an old arithmetic term).
sharp, bold, forward.
a small native herb (Centaurium sebaeoides, syn. Erythraea sebaeoids), with white or pale pink flowers, in the gentian family.
by, by means of (follows a pas/imp.).

particles indicating imperfect aspect and future tense and accompanying subordinate verbs. The nei indicates action here or now. See (Gram. 5.2).
pejorative suffix.

    [Lā Hoʻihoʻi Ea, literally the day sovereignty was restored, a holiday celebrated in the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi. Set on July 31, modern observations of this day include ceremonies taking place at different sites around Hawaiʻi, including a key commemoration at Thomas Square in Honolulu.]

   • air,  breeze,

a general term for infections and infectious diseases; coated tongue, sometimes accompanied by sore throat, the thrush disease of children. Many diseases of miscellaneous nature begin with ʻea and are listed below.

severe headaches, perhaps due to high blood pressure. lit., ʻea at fontanel.

light-brown in color.

extraordinary, incomprehensible, abnormal, deceitful, peculiar, as persons with miraculous powers; such persons. Many ʻeʻepa characters in mythology were born in strange forms, as a plant, an animal, or a piece of rope. cf. ʻepa₁, ʻepaʻepa, kino ʻeʻepa. The Menehune, Nāwā, and Nāmū of Waolani in Nuʻuanu Valley were ʻeʻepa. Trickery or deceit that passes comprehension is also ʻeʻepa.
to crawl, creep, as an insect.
shuddering sensation of revulsion (less strong than mania); to rise in horror, flinch (sometimes interpreted as a portent).
to make a wry face, pout, as in derision; to protrude the lips mockingly.
great pain, agony, tribulation, many small pains; painful.
to breathe hard, pant.
the Chinese lace-necked, or ring-necked dove (Streptopelia chinensis), an early introduction to Hawaiʻi, said to be named for its call ʻeha kō, prolonged pain.
easily hurt, sensitive, having feelings easily hurt; to hurt for no reason.

syllables repeated in chants at ends of verses, affording pleasure by repetition or sameness of sound harmonizing with repetition of sameness of drum beat; similar in function to English tra-la-la but different in mood, tending to be more serious.
a hard, dry cough; to cough.

to laugh merrily, giggle in glee; laughter.
