name recorded for adult stage of hāpuʻu fish.
somewhat crooked, warped; not in sound mind. (Similar to but perhaps less strong than hipa and hepa.)

stone pile (FS 107), especially as used to mark land boundaries; stone image; heap of stones under water (at times fishermen block one end with a net and drive the fish in from the other end), also umu, imu; pillar (Kin. 35.20) ; red-hot stones put inside dressed animals in cooking (also pōhaku ʻeho).
swelling or ulcerous sore, as caused by friction under the arm, tumor.
name of a lua stroke. lit., let the hero of Mānoa return, [it's] evening. (E- is sometimes omitted.)
water or water mixed with fragrant herbs used in sprinkling or gently rubbing a patient to revive him from fainting.
var. name for ʻōlapa₂, Cheirodendron trees.
spray, foam, mist. (Many older people say ehu for ʻehu₁,₂,₃,₄, which is probably the older form; note lack of glottal stops in such forms as ehuehu, ʻehuehu, kaiehu, kēhu, kuehu, luehu, puehu.)
dust; dusty.
pollen.
faint, difficult to see; wisp.

reddish tinge in hair, of Polynesians and not of Caucasians; one with ʻehu hair; reddish-brown complexion said to be characteristic of some ʻehu people; ruddy. (This ʻehu is invariably pronounced with an initial glottal stop.)
the dust of evening. fig., twilight, old age.
same as ʻahuʻawa (Cyperus javanicus).

acre.
hand of bananas. Compare maiʻa for pejorative connotations.

the bird's-nest fern (Asplenium nidus), widespread in the tropics, forming large rosettes and in some forests perching on branches of trees. The fronds are large, entire, sword-shaped. The black midrib is used like the ʻamaʻu fern for decorating pandanus hats. Also ʻākaha. This fern is sometimes called ʻēkaha kuahiwi, mountain ʻēkaha, to distinguish it from the mosses or from ʻēkaha kū moana.
a moss growing on rotted trees. Also limu ʻēkaha.
juvenile or small form of bird's-nest fern.
var. name for limu loloa and limu uaua loli.
black coral (Antipathes grandis), used medicinally.
type of tapa.
a native fern (Elaphoglossum alatum), with entire, narrow fronds 24 to 64 cm long and with, close, parallel veins. The spore-bearing fronds are similar but smaller.
church (the organization, not the building; usually pronounced ʻekalesia).
to cringe, shrink from, draw away from, flinch, wince; to become smaller, shrink.
boom on the right side of a double canoe.
small bag or sack, pocket, purse, scrotum
fussy, overexacting, cranky, particular.
a herringbone design, as in mat plaiting or in the pāpale ʻie.
name of a wind of the island of Kaʻula.
billfold, wallet, small purse.
holder for stone in the sling (maʻa), sometimes a kind of woven basket, but in smaller slings merely a kind of noose.
icecap [i.e. ice bag].
male supporter, jockstrap. lit., basket supporting scrotum.
gunny sack. lit., hairy sack.
short, as a dress or fishline (probably a redup. of ʻeke₂ + -ʻi, transitivizer).

wings.

plant listed (no data).

gunny sack, burlap. lit., grass sack.

agent.

handbag, hand basket, briefcase.
to bend over, crouch, as to hide oneself or an object. fig., secretive, as in love affairs; to keep a secret.
a bird (no data).

a type of banana.
hot-water bag.
ace.
bayonet. cf. kī, to shoot, and ʻēlau waikī.
place where ti plants grow.
Hawaiian tern (Anous sp.).
a stench that draws flies; bad-smelling.
Edinburgh.

redup. of eko; extremely bad-smelling.
same as ʻakoko and koko, shrubs and trees.

ale.

a native fungus (Gnomania iliau), parasitic on leaf sheaths of sugar cane.
time of light, daylight, a term used in kuwā prayers, as to indicate that a new house is free from taboo and may be occupied.
door at the leeward end of a house.
period of darkness.
perhaps same as ʻakiʻaki, a seaweed. Maui.
variety of tapa said to have originated at Kaumakani, Maui; it was dyed with candlenut, pāʻihi, and black mud.

a species of flycatcher with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (Chasiempis sandwichensis sandwichensis), Kauaʻi (C. sandwichensis sclateri), and Oʻahu (C. sandwichensis gayi). The Kauaʻi subspecies is also called ʻāpekepeke. This bird was believed to be the goddess of canoe makers, hence the saying ua ʻelepaio ʻia ka waʻa, the canoe is [marked] by the ʻelepaio [an ʻelepaio bird pecking slowly on a tree trunk for insects signified that the trunk was insect-ridden and not suitable for a canoe (see kani₁); the saying may be applied to any failure]. The name also refers to one who craves fish but does not go fishing, as the cry of the bird was thought to suggest ʻono ka iʻa, ʻono ka iʻa, fish is delicious, fish is delicious.

• a prefix similar in meaning to the causative/simulative hoʻo-. 
   • before short vowels and glottal stop the form is usually hā-, as hāinu, to give to drink, and hāʻawe, to carry. 
   • before consonants, both haʻa- and hā- occur, as haʻalele and hākuʻi. 
   • before glottal stop plus a long vowel, ha- occurs, as haʻāpuka. 
   • for a few bases, derivatives with both haʻa- and hoʻo occur, as haʻakoʻo and hoʻokoʻo, which have the same meanings; with a few bases, meanings differ, as haʻalele and hoʻolele. 
   • a few bases with haʻa- may form another derivative with hoʻo-, as inu, hāinu, and hoʻohāinu; heo, haʻaheo, hoʻohaʻaheo. 
   • before colors the meaning is "-ish, somewhat," as hākea, haʻakea, hāʻeleʻele, hāuliuli. 
   • for clear understanding, delete haʻa- and look up the base.

the pandanus or screw pine (Pandanus odoratissimus), native from southern Asia east to Hawaiʻi, growing at low altitudes, both cultivated and wild. It is a tree with many branches, which are tipped with spiral tufts of long narrow, spine-edged leaves; its base is supported by a clump of slanting aerial roots. The pineapple-shaped fruits are borne on female trees whereas the spikes of fragrant, pollenbearing flowers are borne separately on male trees. Many uses: leaves (lau hala) for mats, baskets, hats; the yellow to red fruit sections for leis, brushes; male flowers to scent tapa, their leaflike bracts to plait mats (see hīnano). (Neal 51) The aerial root (uleule) tip is a good source of vitamin B and cooked in ti leaves was used medicinally, although unpleasant tasting. The tree is called pū hala. The hala lei is much liked today but formerly was not worn on important ventures because hala also means failure. For the same reason some persons will not compose songs about hala. Types of hala are listed below.

It was formerly used both medicinally and in religious ceremonies, as for dedicating new fish nets. According to (HP 17), it is a domesticated form of wild ʻāweu. a lowland tree (Hibiscus tiliaceus), found in many warm countries, some spreading horizontally over the ground forming impenetrable thickets, and some trained on trellises. The leaves are rounded and heart-shaped, the flowers cup-shaped, with five large petals that change through the day from yellow to dull-red. Formerly the light, tough wood served for outriggers of canoes, the bast for rope, the sap and flowers for medicine. (Neal 559–60). Of the two varieties of hau, a rare erect one (hau oheohe) was grown for its bast and a creeping one (hau) was planted for wind-breaks. (HP 196)

an earth-mother goddess equated with Papa, Laʻilaʻi₃, and Kāmehaʻikana, the 'great source of female fertility' (HM 185) who bore children in successive generations. She is also called '[Haumea] … of mysterious forms, Haumea of eightfold forms, Haumea of four-hundred-thousand-fold forms...' (KL. 232). She married Wākea and later married Hāloa, her husband's son by his own daughter Hoʻohokukalani. Haumea had many other husbands. She is considered the mother of Pele and of Pele's many siblings who were born from her mouth or armpits. She presided over childbirth. Beckwith has summarized the many tales about her (HM 276-290). see Kaulu; Punaʻaikoaʻe; Kāmehaʻikana. lit., red ruler.

heiau for stopping rain, or (less frequently) for bringing rain. One such heiau named Imukālua-ua (rain-baking oven) was in the Kaunakakai quadrangle, Molokaʻi; a land section in Puna, Hawaiʻi, also has this name. Rain in leaf packages is said to have been baked in an oven.

the swamp fern (Ceratopteris thalictroides), an edible, somewhat succulent fern, distributed through the tropics. It grows in mud or water, as around taro patches, in tufts about 30 cm high. The fronds are triangular and are finely divided into long, narrow parts. Young fronds are eaten with fresh-water shrimps.
civil case.
to come or go, of many people.
redup. and intensifier of hina, to fall.
name of a legendary koa tree on Kauaʻi that was said to have no trunk.
net made of strong cord used for shark fishing.
various sting rays (Dasyatidae) and eagle rays (Actobatus narinari).
lavish, magnificent, elegant; elegance.
a Kauaʻi peak. see saying, keha.
entanglement, spreading.
soft whistling sound, gust or draft of wind; to whistle.

• a dream or vision (Kin. 15–1) , as while dozing; to dream while dozing;

wild, untamed.

endemic grainy snail (Neritinu graposa), in both fresh and brackish water, eaten both cooked and raw.  also wī, if in fresh water.
a shellfish (Nerita vespertina). Also hapawai.
a pelagic grapsid crab, probably Grapsus tenuicrustatus.

• to hold or carry in the arms, as a child;    • to bear;    • to nurse or tend a child (Hawaiians did not carry children unrelated to them, and commoners did not touch a chief's child; carrying a child symbolized love, kinship, and affection). cf:
    Hiʻiaka, first part of the names of the twelve younger sisters of the goddess Pele...
    hiʻialo, carried in the arms, as a beloved child...
    hiʻikua, carried on the shoulders, as a beloved child...
    hiʻilani, to nurse or care for, as an infant...
    hiʻilei, to carry, tend, and cherish a beloved child...
    hiʻimoʻopuna, to bear a grandchild in the arms...
    hiʻipaka, to care for a child...
    hiʻipoi, to tend, feed, cherish, as a child...
tall, as cliff or mountain.
first part of the names of the twelve younger sisters of the goddess Pele; the youngest and most famous was Hiʻiakaikapoliopele. see (PH).
a rare variety of taro with bronze-red leaf and stem, used in medicine.

Pele's favorite younger sister born from the mouth of Haumea rather than from the bosom, as were the many other Hiʻiaka sisters ((Westervelt p. 69), says there may have been forty sisters). Born as an egg, she was carried under Pele's bosom until she became a young beauty. She is the heroine of the epic concerning her trip from Kīlauea Volcano  to Kauaʻi  to find and fetch Pele's dream lover, Lohi'au; on her long and dangerous journey she transformed many evil moʻo into stones which are still visible (see PH). One of her forms was the palaʻā lace fern used to treat diseases and one of the first plants to grow on new lava. As the physician of the Pele family, she resuscitated Lohiʻau. She instituted the eating of fish from head to tail. She was worshiped by hula dancers. lit., Hiʻiaka in the bosom of Pele.
carried in the arms, as a beloved child.
nearby, in front.
hook used for kala, a fish, and baited with kala, a seaweed.

name of a star said to rise on the night of Hoaka and to vanish on the night of Muku in the month of Welehu.

name of the highest waterfall in Hawaiʻi, and one of the highest in the world, with a vertical drop of about 300 m, at Waipiʻo Valley, Hawaiʻi. see (EM 49), for a famous song.

name of the wife of the famous legendary navigator, Pākaʻa and of the coastal area, Molokaʻi, where she lived. She was lost during labor pains and her husband searched vainly for her, hence the saying applied to fruitless endeavors, Hikauhi i Kaumanamana, Hikauhi is at Kaumanamana [another place on Molokaʻi]. [cf slightly different explanation at (ON 1162)]

various species of reef fishes of the genus Coris. The name hilu may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, lauwili, melemele, moelola, pano (probably same as uli), pāniʻo, pilikoʻa (Paracirrhites forsteri, hawkfish), ʻula, uli. See saying, noʻenoʻe₂.

mother of Kamapuaʻa by Kahikiʻula and referred to in chants by her mother, Kamaunuaniho, in order to save Kamapuaʻa in time of peril (FS 196-203). When she failed to recognize her pig son, Kamapuaʻa, in human form, she exposed herself in humiliation (FS 242-249).
a wife of Wākea and the mother of the island of Molokaʻi, celebrated in the song Molokaʻi Nui a Hina, Great Molokaʻi Child of Hina.

a goddess associated with Kū (upright), with whom she had incestuous relations. Hina in this instance means 'prostrate.' When gathering medicine with their left hands, people prayed to Hina for success. See Hikuikanahele, Kū.
name of a legendary goddess.
the silversword (Argyroxiphium sandwicense).

florida moss (Tillandsia usneoides), an air plant, growing on tree branches and hanging baskets, forming masses of gray, thread-like stems and leaves. It is often substituted for the heliotrope (below) as the flower of Kahoʻolawe, and so called.  Also ʻāhinahina and ʻumiʻumi o Dole, Dole's Whiskers.

native heliotrope (Heliotropium anomalum var. argenteum), a low, spreading beach plant, with narrow, clustered, silvery leaves and small, white, fragrant flowers. As designated by the Territorial legislature in 1923, it represents Kahoʻolawe in the leis of the islands; it is used for tea and medicine.  Called nohonoho puʻuone on Niʻihau.
native geraniums (Geranium cuneatum var. tridens and other native silvery geraniums), shrubs or small trees of the high mountains, with ovate, toothed leaves and red or white flowers.
native artemisia (Artemisia australis).
a variety of sugar cane, gray-green with a rosy flush, the whole covered with a wax bloom; pith dark brown; looks like lahi₂.
dusty miller (Artemisia stelleriana), a perennial herb in the daisy family, from northeastern Asia and eastern North America. The leaves and stems have a white, velvety covering and are aromatic.
a native Hawaiian plant of the water-leaf family (Nama sandwicensis). Niʻihau. cf. (Neal 712).
an unidentified plant.
an unidentified plant.
a Hawaiian star and month name.

vague accounts (HM 214) mention this goddess as being born in the undersea land Kahikihonuakele (wet land Kahiki), and as floating on the sea and becoming a gourd bailer—Hinaikekā (Hina in the bailer) (KL. 235). In some stories she makes tapa in the moon (HM 220). She was also called Hinahanaakamalama (Hina foster-child of the moon), the name of Queen Emma's home in Nuʻu-anu Valley, Honolulu. lit., Hina in the moon. see ʻAikanaka₃; Hema.

goddess of canoe bailers, sometimes called the sister of Hina who was the mother of Māui (HM 219), or equated with the mother of corals, Hinaʻōpūhalakoʻa. Most commonly she took the form of a gourd canoe bailer (kā); Wākea found her floating and took her into his canoe. lit., Hina (in) the bailer. see Hinaikamalama; Pīmoe.

type of stone laid near the coral pile (umu) to attract fish; it was flat on one side and rounded on the other, and was believed to attract manini and young of other fish which resembled it in color. lit., white gray.

small- to moderate-sized, brightly colored wrasses, family Labridae. 
   • In addition to those listed below, hīnālea may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, līpoa, lolo, nīʻau, nuku ʻiʻiwi, nuku ʻiʻiwi ʻula, nuku ʻiʻiwi uli, nuku loa, nuku loa ʻeleʻele. cf. ʻōpule. 
   • hīnālea was eaten raw as an aftertaste for kava. It was prepared in the iʻa hoʻomelu fashion with kukui nuts and chili pepper [nīoi]; 
   • as this had a somewhat offensive smell, the phrase ipu kai hīnālea, dish of hīnālea sauce, was applied rudely to one with unpleasant breath, especially if he had the iʻa kui, nasal discharge.

name of a chief in whose time occurred a famous deluge called kai a ka Hinaliʻi; the Biblical flood (Kin. 6.17) . See saying ʻiliki₁.

goddess of corals and spiny creatures of the sea, appearing as a woman and as a coral reef. From her shells Māui made his famous hook for drawing the islands together. lit., Hina stomach passing coral.

a rare native variety of upland taro, with green leaves, reddish leaf juncture (piko), dark-green petioles, and white corm. Perhaps same as lauloa uliuli.

goddess of food plants (HM 69), also known as Hinahele, and sister of Hinapukuiʻa. She assumed the form of Lea, and as an ʻelepaio flycatcher alighted on trees that canoe makers wanted to cut; if she pecked a tree, canoe makers knew that it was insect ridden and not suitable for a canoe. The spot where she landed on a felled tree was to be the prow; she then ran toward the stern. lit., Hina gathering vegetable food.

fishtail fern (Nephrolepis biserrata cv. furcans), a kind of sword fern, with forked divisions (pinnae). In Kaʻū, leis are made by combining pinnae of this fern (or whole frond) with flower sprays of wāpine (lemon verbena).

water purification festivities on the second night of the month of Welehu (near the end of the year). The people bathed and frolicked in the sea or stream after midnight, then put on their finest tapa and ornaments for feasting and games.

[NB: hoʻāno, listed under ano in the 1986 edition of PE with the 1991 preface,  is misspelled as hō.ano, and in the examples below as Hōano and hōano. In the 1986 edition with the 1984 preface, it is misspelled hō.ʻano, Hōʻano, hōʻano. It is respelled correctly here, as in the 1965 and earlier editions, and as in the Hawaiian Bible. The "Ē kō mākou..." of the Lord's Prayer example in the 1986 editions has been rewritten here as "E ko mākou...", the spelling of the earlier editions and the Hawaiian Bible.]

bay, gulch, valley (as a part of place names such as Honolulu, Honokōhau, Honoliʻi, Honomanu; also in the poetic phrase nā Honō a Piʻilani, the bays beginning with Hono- of Piʻilani [a chief who ruled the bays on Maui, Molokaʻi, and Lānaʻi that were visible from Lahaina]. Hana- occurs similarly as in Hanalei and Hanauma.

bad smelling (less common than hohono).
rite at the end of kapu loulu rituals during which chiefs sat without shifting positions while a kahuna prayed for as long as an hour.
same as kūkae, excrement, and an insulting epithet for commoners.

wild spiderflower (Gynandropsis gynandra), a cosmopolitan tropical hairy annual weed, native to Africa, in the caper family, 30 to 90 cm high, leaves five-parted; flowers spider-like, white with a purple tinge; fruit narrow, cylindrical capsule with many seeds.

the wandering Jew or dayflower (Commelina diffusa), known in many temperate and tropical countries, a creeping weed, rooting at the joints, and bearing grasslike, ovate leaves and small bright-blue flowers. Also honohono wai, and mākolokolo.
a very rare native mint (Haplostachys haplostachya), a downy erect herb with oblong or narrower leaves and white flowers.
a children's game; the child locked fingers of two hands and thrust them into the sand, letting the sand out through a small opening.
the basket grass (Oplismenus hirtellus), a creeping grass that originated in America, called kukui because it is often found under kukui trees.
a variety of honohono₂ [wandering Jew, dayflower]
wandering Jew or zebrina, an ornamental, now naturalized, native to Mexico (Zebrina pendula).
cavern, sea cave.
town name, Hāmākua, Hawaiʻi.
Hong Kong.
a hard lump beside the mons pubis.
mischievous, teasing; to tease.
name of the capital city in the Hawaiian Islands lit., sheltered bay.
windbreak.
mob, angry crowd.
name of a design for Niʻihau mats.
suddenly, abruptly and without reason.
middle section of a canoe; central section of a canoe fleet, as fishing iheihe fish; main section, as of an army.
base of a breaker.
a variety of sugar cane, a dark brown-red mutant of manulele, with purple leaf sheaths and leaves. (HP 221, 225).  It was formerly used in medicine, and is one of the best canes for eating raw.
hawksbill turtle (Chelonia); the shell of this turtle was used as medicine for the disease called ʻea and was used for combs and fans.
a game in which player and opponent sat with legs crossed and tried to unseat each other; to play this game.
a game in which one boy sat astride the back of another who was down on all fours; to play this game.
a tapa pattern said to have its surface raised in ridges like corduroy.
a tortoise, perhaps the introduced land tortoise of the genus Gopherus. lit., foreign turtle.
a variety of turtle.
a variety of thick-shelled turtle. lit., coarse turtle.
crowded, thick.
a variety of turtle. lit., white-headed turtle.

a very active former of caus/sim. derivatives. hoʻo- is treated as a prefix because it occurs only before bases; unlike prefixes, however, it takes the stress of a word, as does the following base; thus hoʻouna, to send, bears stress on the u and on the first o. hoʻo- usually precedes stems beginning with the vowels i- and u- and all the consonants except the glottal stop. important meanings follow...
causation and transitivization, as pono, correct; hoʻoponopono, to correct.
pretense, as kuli, deaf; hoʻokuli, to feign deafness.
similarity, as kamaliʻi, children; hoʻoka maliʻi, childish.

no meaning, as kāholoholo, to hurry; hoʻokāholoholo, to hurry. The meanings of some hoʻo- derivatives are quite different from the meanings of the stems, as maikaʻi, good; hoʻomaikaʻi, to congratulate.

the daughter of Wākea and Papa, the ancestors of the Hawaiians. Wākea instituted taboo nights so that he might sleep with Hoʻohoku. The root -hoku may be cognate with Tahitian hotu, to produce fruit, and Tongan fotu, to appear; if so, the translation would be 'to bear fruit in the heavens'.

a game of tossing ti leaves into Malama Crater at Puna, Hawaiʻi, and dedicating them to Ka-moho-aliʻi

A game played only at Malamakī, Puna, Hawaiʻi. A player would hold a ti leaf in his hand, chant ʻO kēlā kī, ʻo kēia kī, na Kamohoaliʻi kaʻu kī, lele!. That ti, this ti, my ti is for Kamohoaliʻi, fly! If the wind was right and the chant correctly rendered, the ti would fly off and return to the sender. lit., make the ti fly

a dancer who was turned into a balancing rock by Pele at Puna, Hawaiʻi...  A girl friend of Pele's little sister, Hiʻiakaikapoliopele. When Hiʻiaka left to fetch Pele's dream lover, Lohiʻau, from Kauaʻi, she entrusted Hōpoe and her favorite lehua groves to Pele. Pele became jealous of Hiʻiaka, burned the lehua groves, and changed Hōpoe into a balancing rock at Keaʻau, Puna, Hawaiʻi (HM 181). The stone may still be there, and waves lapping against it suggest movement; hence Hōpoe, famous as a hula dancer, is mentioned in songs as ka wahine hoʻolewa i ke kai, the woman shaking hips in the sea. lit., fully developed, as a lehua flower. Other names are Hōpoe-lehua and Hōpoe-wahine.

This dance originated on Molokaʻi, an island famous for sports. Many of the songs contain taunts, as a laʻa kō kū i ke aʻu, now you are jabbed by the swordfish. cf. hula kuʻi under kuʻi, joined.

[In l984, the reef triggerfish (Rhinecanthus rectangulus) was selected as the official State Fish of Hawai‘i after a popular vote and the approval of the State Legislature.  The State Fish’s official term of office lasted five years, and there was no re-election campaign.  In May of 2006 Governor Linda Lingle signed a bill that permanently established the humuhumunukunukuāpua‘a as the State Fish of Hawai’i.]

an endemic woody, branching climber (Freycinetia arborea) growing luxuriantly in forests at altitudes of about 300 to 600 m. The ringed stems end in tufts of long, narrow, spiny leaves, in the center of which flowers are borne on cylindrical spikes surrounded by leafy bracts, which are orange or green with orange bases. (Neal 54) ʻIeʻie was one of five plants used on the hula altar (see palai).

all Hawaiian kinds of sandalwood (Santalum spp.), shrubs and trees, with fragrant heart wood, small pale-green or gray-green leaves, small, dull-red or greenish flowers, and small purple fruits. From about 1790 to 1830 sandalwood trees were cut and exported to China.

skin not easily bruised or infected; one with such a skin is said to emit an acrid (ʻawa) odor; a strong-smelling fish caught by him (as pualu or palani) is said to become more offensive in odor.

small to large native shrubs (all species of Sida, especially S. fallax), bearing yellow, orange, greenish, or dull-red flowers; some kinds strung for leis. The flowers last only a day and are so delicate that about 500 are needed for one lei. Fruits of maʻo (Abutilon grandifolium), when green and soft, are used with ʻilima leis, one fruit at each end of the lei ; or the pale-green, cap-like calyx of the ʻilima flower is used. A mild laxative for babies is made by squeezing out the juice of flowers; this is called kanakamaikaʻi. The ʻilima was designated in 1923 by the Territorial Legislature as the flower of Oʻahu. It is related to the hibiscus.  see songs, nōweo, pue₁.

a rare ʻilima with bronze-red flowers, domesticated on Oʻahu. lit., kukui candle ʻilima.

an affectionate term for affinal relatives, or in-laws of in-laws, or relatives usually not related by blood; inoa may be followed by a kinship term indicative of generation (as moʻopuna, kaikamahine, keiki, makua, kupuna), or of the common relative (as puluna, hūnōna.) A grandchild's spouse's relatives united by affection to the speaker might thus be called inoa moʻopuna. Similarly the cousins of a puluna (parents-in-law of an offspring) might be inoa puluna, and the cousins or in-laws of a parent might be inoa makua. The relationship might also extend to close family friends.  (in fast speech often preceded by ke)

Hawaiian hawk (Buteo solitarius), an endemic and endangered hawk with dark and light color phases, confined to forests on the island of Hawaiʻi, where it is regarded by some as an ʻaumakua. The ʻio signified royalty because of its lofty flight, and hence occurs in such names as ʻIo-lani, royal hawk.

the watermelon (Citrullus lanatus), a wide-spreading vine from tropical Africa, with large, lobed leaves and yellow flowers. It is grown for its edible fruits, which are round or oblong, green or green with light stripes, and full of sweet, juicy, rose-colored pulp surrounding flat, black seeds, The watermelon was introduced to Hawaiʻi about 1792 and thrived until the melon fly arrived about 1910. Among many varieties that were developed were three outstanding ones: ipu huluhulu, ipu poʻo kanaka, and ipu oloolo. Today watermelons are again cultivated successfully because the fruits are commonly wrapped in paper or cloth during early stages.

a small, high-mountain fern (Asplenium adiantum-nigrum), with shiny, brown stems and triangular or ovate, subdivided, stiff fronds, the spores numerous, often found covering the under side of the fronds. Known in many countries.

an endemic fern (Asplenium rhipidoneuron) with narrow, feather-shaped fronds, which are stiff, 10 to 30 cm long, dark-green, the divisions pointed and obliquely cut, their stems bearing many dark scales.

the curly-leaved maidenhair (Adiantum tenerum f. farleyense), an ornamental fern much like the ʻiwaʻiwa hāuli, but the leaf subdivisions much larger, more deeply cut, fringed and overlapping. lit., curly maidenhair.
lit., Australian maidenhair.
the fan maidenhair fern (Adiantum tenerum), with each of the last fan-shaped subdivisions split into five to ten segments.

the Venus-hair, a kind of maidenhair fern (Adiantum capillus-veneris), known in many warm countries, both wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi. The fronds are subdivided into many small, bright-green, fan-shaped divisions, borne on slender, black stems.

a sea bean (Mucuna gigantea), native from southeast Asia, east into Polynesia, a high-growing vine, bearing greenish flowers and large pods, each pod containing two to four round and flattened seeds, black-spotted or brown. In Hawaiʻi, the seeds, known as pēkaʻa, are found on the beaches, and are used medicinally for their strong purgative effect and are also strung for leis.

bamboo pipes, varying in length from .3 to about 1 m; usually with one end open. A player held one vertically in each hand tapping down on a mat or on the ground. The tone varied according, to the size of the tube. Several musicians might play at once. (UL 143–4), (Roberts 53) Barrèrre suggests (Barrère 1980:11) that kāʻekeʻeke as the name for bamboo pipes seems to have originated with Emerson. She quotes Andrews (who refers to (Laie)) as saying the name applied to coconut-tree drums. It is also used as a verb. Also ʻohe kāʻekeʻeke or pahūpahū.

a Mānoa beauty, the wife of Kauhi. In the legend gossips told Kauhi that she was unfaithful. He led her to a forest on Ka'ala mountain and slowly beat her to death and buried her under an ʻōhiʻa tree. Passers-by restored her to life. (HM 152-153). In the story as told by Westervelt (Old Honolulu, pp. 128-130), her cruel lover, a Waikiki chief, killed her three times; each time she was resuscitated by an owl god, Pueoaliʻi. lit., the pandanus of Puna.

method of fishing with a large net placed in deep water where fish fed or where bait had been strewn; to fish thus.
a method of birdcatching: all save a few lehua blossoms were plucked and the remaining flowers were gummed so that birds would be stuck; to catch birds thus.
plural and diminutive of kāheka; small sea pool or pools; artificial salt pan.
flow of blood, hemorrhage; to have such.
gourd drumbeat: the gourd is thumped down on a pad; it is then raised with the left hand and is struck with two quick slaps of the fingers of the right hand.
name of a star, seen in the month ʻIkuwā.
redup. and intensifier of kāhela₁, to lie spread out...; to sprawl, kāhela₂, a hula step, kāhela₃, gourd drumbeat:...
adze
decorated for a journey, as with a lei.
to flow.
to be entangled.
species of small colored shells, found particularly on Niʻihau; perhaps so called because the shells were used by chiefs.
name of an ancient chief associated with Niʻihau. lit., the royal going.
flowing.
to weed and stir up the soil.
to subincise or circumcise. lit., cut penis.
to miss, fail, not succeed; to hit by mistake; foiled or thwarted in an attempt.
old var. of kakahiaka, morning.
to give generously or lavishly with the heart and not with expectation of return.
to polish, as a bowl.
entanglement, perplexity, involvement, blocking; entangled, choked, as by weeds; blocked, involved, as with the law (Mat. 5.40),  trapped, framed (slang).
of disapproval or disbelief; the vowels are sometimes nasalized and the last two greatly leangthened, spoken with rising inflection. Horrors!
zoo.
sink (basin).
place for cleansing; purgatory.
buttocks.
to stretch out smooth by rubbing, as in making tapa. lit., rub stretch out.

Tahiti. The sky was divided into five areas beginning with the term Kahiki: 
      Kahikimoe, horizon; lit., prostrate Kahiki. 
      Kahikikū, sky just above the horizon; lit., upright Kahiki. 
      Kahikikapapanuʻu, the next layer; lit., Kahiki the elevated stratum
      Kahikikapapalani, high in the sky, almost directly overhead; lit., Kahiki the sky (or god) stratum.
      Kahikikapuihōlanikekuʻina, the sky directly overhead; lit., sacred Kahiki at Hōlani the meeting place
any foreign country, abroad, foreign.
a variety of banana, common wild on Maui. Kinds are kahiki hae, kahiki mauki, and kahiki puhi.

name of a legendary tree and place in the uplands of Kauaʻi (FS 233), probably a var. of Kahilikolo. Kamapuaʻa used the tree as a club with which he knocked away (kuehu) his foesʻ clubs from their hands, enabling him to kill them.
name of a navigation star, said to be named for one of the eight steersmen of Hawaiʻiloa.
name of a district or ahupuaʻa on Maui. lit., great Tahiti.
name of the first Hawaiian.
finery, ornaments; to wear finery, dress up; to harness.
somewhat old.
war finery, formerly, shield, helmet, feather cape.
to have lost the red glow of dawn.
trinity, three in one.
star name (no data).
to rise higher, of the sun, to a stage between kahikole and kau i ka lolo (noon).
the crape myrtle (Lagerstroemia indica), an ornamental shrub from China, with small oval leaves and panicles of pink, white, or purple crapy flowers.

a small tree (Grevillea banksii) from Australia, related to the silky oak, ʻoka kilika, but the leaves with fewer subdivisions and the flowers red or cream-white. This is a later application of kāhili to a plant. Flowers not used for leis on head or around neck because of it irritating hairs, but made into leis for hats by sewing alternate rows of flower clusters and own leaves on pandanus band.
Kāhili ginger (Hedychium gardnerianum), from the Himalaya region; much like the white ginger but with a more open flower head, the flowers with narrow yellow segment and one bright-red stamen apiece.
a seaweed, probably Turbinaria ornata.
to spray.
medical combination of juices of the gourd and the puʻukaʻa sedge.
name of a legendary koa tree on Kauaʻi said to consist of branches without a trunk. lit., the creeping tangle.
lua fighting stroke.
currycomb. lit., horse comb.
small kāhili carried in the hand.
place to sleep, bed, cot.
wood shavings; rubbing, cutting, etc.
to knock down, take advantage of, deceive.
name of a legendary chief in whose time was a great sea flood (HM 315), (Malo Ch. 58), perhaps a tsunami.
residence, address.
to rub with oil, grease, petroleum jelly; to anoint (kā-₂ + hinu).
high-backed comb with long prongs (ʻō) such as worn by the Spanish.
to lean to one side (kā-₂ + hinu). cf. the more common hiō.
tipsy.
drunk.
back or side comb used hold hair in place. lit., comb to pin down.
fine-toothed comb, as used for removing dandruff or head lice (ʻuku).
to shave the whiskers; barber.
dark pupil, as of the eye (kā- + hiwa).
sacred vine.
to strike, break; to strike of a fish at a hook (ka-₂ + hoa).
beginning of a chant, with others then joining in; to begin a chant.
to appeal, intercede.
kind of sorcery prayer spoken in a moderate or natural voice.

a god, said to be in the Pele family, sometimes associated with the underworld. During makahiki rituals for Kū, he was impersonated by a naked man, and was presented the eye of a human victim or of a bonito (aku) or ulua fish. lit., the chiefly companion.
unidentified star.
name of a star.
of surprise or anger.
indicating surprise, following bases.
hasty, nimble, swift, quick; to move fast, progress rapidly. cf. holo, to run; pule kāholo.
to sew with long stitches; basting; sennit lashings on royal canoes.

the "vamp" hula step, more common in modern than in ancient dance, consisting of four counts: (1) one foot is extended to the side, (2) the other is brought alongside, (3, 4) this is repeated on the same side; then the four steps are repeated on the opposite side; to execute this step.
name of a star.
globe of the earth.
level landing place, as after fording a stream or coming down from a cliff.
dirt embankment.

the only uninhabited major Hawaiian Island. In prehistoric times 80 men, sent front Hawaiʻi, dug a well ten fathoms deep at Keanapou. lit., the taking away [as by currents], see Kanaloa₄ and saying, kūpala₄.

honored attendant, guardian, nurse, keeper of ʻunihipili bones, regent, keeper, administrator, warden, caretaker, master, mistress; pastor, minister, reverend, or preacher of a church; one who has a dog, cat, pig, or other pet. According to (Emerson 2), kahu "implies the most intimate and confidential relations between the god and its guardian or keeper, while the word kahuna suggests more of the professional relation of the priest to the community." cf. kahu hipa, kahu hoʻoponopono, kahu mālama, kahu waiwai, and ex., ʻanāʻanā.
to tend or cook at an oven fire; to build an oven fire; to burn, as lime in a pit; one who tends an oven, a cook. fig., to seethe with hot rage.
base of a quilt on which the pattern (lau) is appliquéd; this base is above the layer of cotton or wool. The pili is below it.
name of a star.
house foundation or site.
subject, as of a discussion, basis for work; foundation principles, is a political platform; work site.
threshing floor.
fire builder; to build and tend a fire.
zoo.
sledding course.
radio broadcasting station. lit., site for making voice fly.
meeting place. lit., site for shelter.
airport.
staging area, as in warfare.
battleground; place used for competitive sports or contests. lit., site for attack.
to cook taro or vegetable food; to keep the store of such food; to make poi; a keeper or cook. same as kahu umu or kahūmu.
headman of a land division.
battlefield.
air base.
tennis court.
fire station. lit., place quench fire.
any ball-playing area, as a base-ball diamond, football field, tennis court.
golf course.
one who takes care of an image or a god; priest.
playground.
royal guardian in the family of a high chief.
submarine base.
master or practitioner of sorcery and counter sorcery. see ex., ʻanāʻanā.
ignoramus, one without background, trade, profession, knowledge; to be such.
bowling alley.
place of happiness, comfort, pleasure (named for Maliʻo, a mythical woman renowned for entertaining with music and for her ability in love magic).
solar system.
terra firma, the solid earth. fig., security.
stadium; playground or athletic field of any kind. lit., site for play.
deputy or regent in the days of the monarchy. lit., government caretaker.
pastor of a church.
unidentified star name.
unidentified star name.
foster parent (of adopted children).
shepherd.
administrator.
of surprise or anger.
Pleiades.
coachman.
to offer food and prayers to a god or to the spirit of a deified person.
one who tends a child, as a nurse.
schoolmaster, school supervisor.
school superintendent.
to overturn, overthrow, capsize, upset.
to change, alter.
land shells (Philonesia spp.).
sport or mutant, as of sweet potato.
name of a star.
revolution, revolutionist; to over-throw the government. Also hoʻokahuli aupuni.
unsteady, shaky, rickety, variable, unsettled; to sway, reel, tip, rock, totter; tossed about, as a ship.
coachman, groom.
turned completely over, upside down.
athletic contest, especially championship match.
crescent-shaped disposition of soldiers on a battlefield.
variety of sweet potato.
a lua fighting stroke.
nurse.
custodian, caretaker.
warden of a district.
housekeeper.
legal guardian of minors.
nurse.
warden of a prison.
person who cared for the chief's excrement so that it would not fall into the possession of a sorcerer.
mate of a ship.
oven cooking; to cook.
filth-eating sorcerer [insulting term].
sorcerer who practices black magic and counter sorcery, as one who prays a person to death.
teaching preacher, minister, sorcerer.
an expert who diagnoses, as sickness or pain, by feeling the body...
preacher, especially an itinerant preacher.
medical expert who induced pregnancy.

malevolent sorcerer, as one who inflicts illness by gesture, as rubbing his own head to give the victim a severe headache or head injury. Sometimes the victim might imitate tha gesture and send the affliction back to the sorcerer.
agricultural expert.
priest who increased population by praying for pregnancy.
a priest who functioned in ceremonies for the deification of a king (Malo 105) or who detected symptoms of sorcery in one sick or dead (HP 72: 322).
to sprinkle tightly, especially with salt.
place where food is cooked in an underground oven, as in a cookhouse; tending of the oven.
carving expert, sculptor.
canoe builder.
caretaker of images, who wrapped, oiled, and stored them, and carried them into battle ahead of the chief.
priest or expert who observed the skies for omens.
medical doctor, medical practitioner, healer. lit., curing expert.
a priest who induced spirits to possess a patient so that he might then drive the spirits out, thus curing the patient. lit., spirit priest.
high priest and councilor to a high chief; office of councilor.
high priest.
high chief's trusted attendant of royal blood who had charge of his tobacco and pipes; he lighted them and drew a few puffs before presenting them to the chief. lit., guardian of tobacco (Eng.)
herdsman, keeper of cattle, cattle owner, rancher; to care for cattle.
librarian, custodian of books.
the high chief who attended an infant chief, carried him, and sat him on his lap (ʻūhā). Also ʻūhā.
oven tender; to tend an oven.
one in charge of water rights and division, water master.
wet nurse (also kahu wale).
trustee, executor. lit., custodian of wealth or property.
perhaps a transitivizer.
contraction ka mea i, the one who did. cf. ka₁; ke, the one who will or should.
prefix to six kinship terms used as terms of reference: kaikaina, kaikoʻeke, kaikuaʻana, kaikunāne, kaikuahine, kaikamahine.
swollen, bloated.
gravy, sauce, dressing, soup, broth.
similar to keu. My, how much! How very! How terrific!
of displeasure, vexation, annoyance, prolonged to indicate greater force.
to pull, as weeds.
fish net or seine; snare or noose for birds.
snood of a fishhook.
a decayed tooth that requires extraction.
the chant during which dancers appear and leave; to come dancing out before an audience;

a variety of taro, the corms of which are fragrant when cooked and, though tough, yield excellent poi. Kinds are qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, kea, keʻokeʻo (said to be reserved for chiefs), koi, nenene, pala, ʻulaʻula, uliuli, welo ʻeka.
fast asleep (used with hiamoe.)
to swing, as arms.
to resound from a distance.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., fish touching human skin.
to come in flocks, as followers to a generous chief.
weakened and watery fluid, as coffee, thinned-down milk; to be watery.
flood...
raging sea so dangerous that man cannot survive. lit., supernatural sea.
large traveling company.
hard type of rock, used for adzes.
indolent, lazy, unskilled; such a person.
to support a sick or intoxicated person between two other persons. lit., lead like a kite.
an extreme low tide with reef exposed. lit., dry sea.
to sit in silence, as at a meeting. cf. mū, silence.
bonito lure made of shell; bone fishhook; barbless deep-sea hook composed of two small hooks.
diaper.
tidal wave. lit., sea of Pele.
rising or high tide. lit., encircling sea.
name of a long prayer used after the kauila celebration at a temple dedication, probably short for poʻo kea, white head or bleached skull, since the sea water (kai) used was held in a skull.
sea where a moving current is visible. lit., current sea.
sea too deep to walk in lit., swimming sea.
community, neighborhood, village.
name of a pleasant, gentle trade-wind breeze, famous in song, at Waiʻanae, Oʻahu.
to move slowly along.
rising tide; sea washing higher on land than usual. lit., rising sea.
tidal wave. lit., mounting sea.
star name.
to disturb, bother.
Black Sea.
ebbing sea. lit., decreasing sea.
to walk with feet far apart, as an infant; to straddle, as on a horse.
to take life philosophically as it comes, sometimes in poverty, sometimes in wealth.
a poetic expression referring to the channels between the islands; always follows nā. Eight is a formulistic number.
group of relatives who faithfully serve and care for a chief during illness; perhaps related to ʻiewe, placenta.
Makahiki festivals prayer.
receding sea or wave.
taboo place along the shore where outcasts (kauwā) or breakers of certain taboos were drowned that they might be offered as sacrifices; one such place was at Kewalo in Honolulu. lit., slippery sea.
to walk, move, proceed, walk in line or in succession, as of a parade; to walk holding on to something or with uncertainty, as a child learning to walk; to move, as in checkers.
any place in the sea or on the reef where a footing may be obtained. lit., sea walk upright.
sauce, as made of crushed shrimp and coconut cream. lit., red sauce.
flowing sea, especially one that goes through a sluice gate into fish ponds.
dizzy, dizziness.
a fine meshed fish net, similar to kāʻili.
deep sea; high tide.
ebbing sea. lit., returning sea.
to exit dancing, as in a hula.
running sea or current.
calm sea water, especially as left to evaporate in a pool so as to form a crust of salt.
parade, procession; to march in a parade.
sea with strong current, undertow.
to drag along; to force to go against one's will.
a type of stone (no data). lit., the snout of the pig.
a lua fighting stroke.
smooth, unwrinkled.
small-meshed net.
hard, rigid; stingy, close-fisted, hard-hearted, harsh; to refuse help; to deny a request; to strut pompously; persistent.
sea-urchin sauce (the crushed shells were placed in salted water; afterwards the liquid was usually strained and added to the flesh of the ʻina).
lavender, reddish-purple, so called because of the color of the sauce.

a climber (Strongylodon ruber, misidentified locally as S. lucidus), in the bean family, endemic in Hawaiʻi, with three-parted leaves and large seeds. The flowers are clustered, red, and shaped like narrow beaks.
cider.
cultivated patch; bank of taro patch.
• to lead,    • support,    • lift up; raise.
carrying, leading, etc.
relative of a junior sibling line.
Caesar. (Bib.)
salt water and ʻōlena root used to remove evil influences. lit., freeing salt water.
strong sea. lit., male sea.
creeping with age; aged (a proper name in some legends for an old hag).
sap, sapwood.
fat, as of pork.
white sea foam, especially as washed up on a beach.
enema composed of sea water and raw crushed kukui nuts. Also kaikuehu and kaīkū.
station of the cross (Catholic); procession of the cross.
tide beginning to flow in. lit., shooting sea.
a wasting disease, emaciation.
policeman.
sea with a strong current.
fat sauce, as made from the liver of the parrot fish (uhu) and eaten with the flesh of the fish.
watery fluid of the bowels.
brother-in-law or male cousin-in-law of a male; sister-in-law or female cousin-in-law of a female.
sea too shallow to float a canoe but good for seeking shellfish. lit., thumping sea, because the canoe thumps the coral.
shallow sea within the reef, lagoon. lit., reef sea.
one so old that he is carried in a net; bedridden (a favorite figure of speech; cf. kani koʻo)
to enter dancing, as in a hula.
rough, strong sea.
straits. lit., space sea.
mid-tide.
enema.
countryman; backwoodsman; sparsely inhabited place; countrified, rustic. lit., back person.
enema.
a rough sea with undercurrent, as pulling back and forth on a beach, undertow.
guards posted at the entrance to the hale nauā enclosure (Malo 191) Emerson (Malo 200) lists this as kaikuone.
Gulf of Mexico.
style, fashion; stylish.
lower sea, i.e., western sea, where the sun sets...
very dark ocean water.  lit., fire charcoal sea.
fishing grounds.
to carry or go to and fro.

• runner on sweet potato vine; 
   • string of fish, string or fiber of any kind on which fish are strung.
to snatch, grab, take by force, seize, abduct, usurp. (see song, (EM 58–9))
to cast for fish.
fine net as used for ʻōpelu fishing.
to gasp, labor for breath

• snatching, 
   • pulling, especially of a newly carved canoe hauled from the mountains to the sea.
to march in step or proceed in unity, as soldiers; to lead together.
to divide.
to plunder, rob, seize, as in premeditated violence.
to die suddenly, as by stroke or accident.
tutelary star of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
to plunder, rob, seize, usually without premeditation.
Cairo.
Inland Sea (Japan).
sea where octopuses are caught with lure, fig., the deep sea.
thyme (Thymus vulgaris), from southern Europe, a small plant with small leaves, in the mint family, used to flavor food.
sea at a point or cape.
Dead Sea.
low tide
Dead Sea.
corpus Christi procession, so called because first communicants march. lit., parade for-the-first-time.
quiet sea, as in a calm cove; low tide.
low tide, as when much of the reef is exposed. lit., dry sea.
to abduct.
diamond. see song, hulali₁.
Diamond Head. lit., Diamond Hill.
mid-tide.
a kind of Spanish clover, an erect fodder plant (Desmodium canum), from the West Indies, a legume with three-parted leaves, pink flowers, and small, narrow, four-to-eight-jointed pods.
receding sea, especially immediately before a tidal wave. lit., shrinking sea.
middle tide, when the tide begins to recede (And); perhaps also similar to kaiʻokia.
demon.

ceremony initiating boys, usually at age of six, after which they were permitted to wear a malo and join the men in the mua, men's house; henceforth they might not eat with women; to perform the ceremony. lit., thrust to the mua house.
kind.

order, succession, sequence.  
same as kaʻi₁
   • to lead, direct, 
   • lift up and carry; 
   • to walk or step in a row or procession...
hit, struck; strike! destroy (said by a sorcerer invoking eternal destruction upon a victim); incantation.
hollow-head; brainless. Kauaʻi.
central part of a canoe, just aft of the point where the forward outrigger boom is attached to the hull (perhaps from kā i nā liu, bail the bilge).
place name at Kona, Hawaiʻi, said to be the name of a canoe bailer for Keawe-nui-a-ʻUmi.

• graceful prancing motion; 
   • to toss, as a ship.
manner of walking, gait; pace, step.
name of a mother ʻuaʻu, bird.
coconut cream.
Why not; I thought, presumed, or assumed (but it was not so).
high tide, big sea.
possession of an altar by a god.
high sea.
a lua fighting stroke; fish was taboo to learners. lit., the hawk.
a plant mentioned in poetry, as ka nani o ka pua kaioʻe, the beauty of the kaioʻe blossoms; a lizard god of the same name is associated with this plant.
to grow irregular and scrubby, as unpruned hau trees
Panicum colliei, kind of grass. Niʻihau.
to bear a second crop of sweet potatoes.
Darien Sea.
name of a long prayer in a temple service.
coyote.
separated by sea, spared, set apart, separated (see kānāwai).
water of purification composed of sea water or water with salt and ʻōlena (turmeric root); to purify thus.
ceremony of tying fine white tapa (ʻoloa) as a malo on an image.
calm, tranquil sea.  fig., peace of mind.
to be such.
giblet gravy.
gravy. lit., sauce to sop up.
high sea, high tide, full sea, spring tide.
high or rising tide, high waves.
a churning, gasping sea.
breaking waves or surf.
sea where currents meet.
mid-tide, quiet sea.
hanger for ipu, calabashes.
a sand-dune sea, said either of a sea at very low tide which leaves the sand exposed, or of a rough sea that washes up sand dunes.
sea with meeting diagonal waves, said figuratively, of Pearl Harbor lochs. lit., sea blowing diagonally.
typhoon.
crazy, restless, wild, agitated sea,

to continue, repeat.

to hill up sweet potatoes. (Kep. 157), (HP 148).

the deep blue sea
sea at full tide, mounting sea.
breaking sea, breakers, whitecaps. lit., resounding sea.

calm, gentle sea. lit., feminine sea.
to rinse, clean.
arched; curving from end to end, as the top of a canoe.
cluster.
gas.
domesticated duck; to quack.
odorous, either fragrant or otherwise; to make an odor.
to excrete; dirty, excreta (a euphemism, taught to children).
to fish, as for uhu, parrot fish, with a square net (FS 39) or ulua with hook and line but no pole; net or nets dropped in a semicircle in shallow water, as for mullets or ʻōʻio.
to roll, whirl, turn over; to revolve, as a wheel; to turn aside, deviate; rolling, turning, etc.

name of a place at Kohala, Hawaiʻi, celebrated in song for the tests held there for the presence of sharks: ti stalks (ʻau kī), whose bark had been beaten off (kākā), were thrown into the water; if the stalks were pulled under this was a sign of the presence of sharks and the natives climbed the steep cliff trail rather than swim.

spry, lively, quick; to run.
name of a star.
strip of barren land near the sea shore; shoal.
to go quickly.
solitary, unique, outstanding.
idle chatter; to talk idly; to wander aimlessly.
to torture to death by flaying or piercing. lit., strike poke.
immature, unripe.

handle, as of a bucket, pot, basket, purse; strings by which a netted (kōkō) calabash is hung; woman's scarf (Niʻihau); to tie on; to encircle with a band, specifically, to stretch the taboo cord before the entrance of a chief's house (this cord was said to fall of its own accord if a relative approached).
to go in file, wander.
tail of a kite.
ancient name of a disease, the symptoms of which suggest appendicitis in various stages.
long, fatiguing, as a trip,
name of a star.
slow, slow moving.
scarce, sparse, rare, few, uncommon; seldom, rarely; precious (1 Sam. 3.1, in sense of rare) .
name of a star.
sequence, one of a series, branch, success.
a series of precipices; consisting of such.
powder horn, cartridge box.
a disease whose symptoms suggest appendicitis.
bow for shooting arrows; crossbow; the shooting of a bow; bent, as a bow; to shoot, as a bow.

a sweet potato, usually qualified by the terms ʻili paheʻe, smooth skin, or ʻili pohole o Keawe, scraped skin of Keawe.

thin, stooped.

our, ours (a-form, plural, inclusive).

gray nickers (Caesalpinia major, misidentified locally as C. crista), a straggly bramble, a pantropical vine indigenous to Hawaiʻi, with thorny branches and leaf stems and with small yellow flowers. Within each large spiny pod are two or three gray marble-like seeds, which are used for leis, also powdered for medicine.
yellow nickers (Caesalpinia bonduc), today commonly called Hawaiian pearls, similar to the gray nickers, but with yellowish-gray instead of gray seeds. Also hihikolo.
cormorant.
silver money.
half-grown manini, a fish.

proclamation.

dye container, probably so called because the edge of the container was hit (kā) with the bamboo stamp to dislodge excess dye before printing the tapa.

name of three woods (kauila, nīoi, ʻohe) believed to be the tree forms of two male gods (Kāneikaulana-ʻula and Kahuilaokalani) and one goddess (Kapo); the wood was considered deadly poisonous at Mauna Loa, Molokaʻi only; small pieces of the wood and roots were used in black magic.

sorcery god represented by images made of the wood of three trees at Maunaloa, Molokaʻi. The trees, believed poisonous, were the nīoi, entered by the god Kāneikaulanaʻula (Kāne at red resting place); the kauila, entered by Ka-huilaokalani (the lightnings of the heavens), believed by some to be a brother of Pele; and the ʻohe tree, entered by the goddess Kapo. The first image of nīoi wood was carved by a Molokaʻi man grateful for a gambling victory. (HM 111). Chips from these trees were used in sorcery.  Only the god Maʻiola could render such sorcery harmless. A Kālaipāhoa image is on display at the Bishop Museum (Buck, Figures 297, 298). lit., dagger carving.

land section, channel, stream, valley, elementary school, field, street, and shopping center, Honolulu, said to have been named by Prince Lot (afterwards Kamehameha V) in 1856. Kalihi in Honolulu is famous in legend as the home of Pele's sister Kapo (HM 186), and of Haumea, Pele's mother who is identified with Papa, the wife of Wākea. She had many adventures at Kalihi and saved her husband Wākea, who was being taken away for sacrifice, by embracing him. His bonds loosened and the two disappeared into a tree. Kaʻieʻie was a heiau here for her worship.

a pig demigod... The pig demigod whose rootings created valleys and springs. He leaned against the cliffs at Kaliuwaʻa, Oahu (where a troughlike depression is still visible) to allow his family to climb up his body and escape Chief ʻOlopana₁. He had many affairs and is a symbol of lechery. He exchanged ribald taunts with Pele and then called on his plant forms — olomea, hala (pandanus), ʻuhaloa, ʻamaʻumaʻu (ferns) — to block her advancing fires, which they did (FS 228-229). He finally mated with Pele, taking for himself Hilo, Hāmākua, and Kohala, and allotting Kaʻū, Puna, and Kona to Pele. When he fought the dog Kūʻīlioloa he called on his kukui, ʻuhaloa, and ʻāmaʻumaʻu forms to hold the dog's mouth open; he then multiplied himself into many pigs and entered the mouth to kill the dog (FS 214-215). Other forms included a handsome man, kūkaepuaʻa grass, clouds, the humuhumunukunukuāpuaʻa fish, and the god Lono. lit., hog man. see Makaliʻi₄; ʻOlopana₁. (FS 196–249). see texts.
a straggling native shrub (Hedyotis fluviatilis var. kamapuaana), found in Punaluʻu Valley, Oʻahu, where the pig god stole chickens.

a multitude of descendants; one of the names for the wondrous (kāmehaʻi) goddess Haumea, who presided over childbirth. She was thought to have borne numerous children to one husband, then to have gone to Kahiki, later returning as a young woman to bear numerous more children; she did this for many generations; hence her name is synonymous with prolificness.

the primrose willow (Ludwigia octivalvis syn. Jussiaea suffruticosa var. ligustraefolia), a perennial herb .6 to 1.2 m high, distributed through the tropics in wet places. Its yellow flowers develop singly at the axils of the narrow leaves. Fruiting capsules are cylindrical, many-seeded. The plant is used medicinally.  This name may be qualified by the terms lau liʻi and lau nui.

a kind of knotweed (Polygonum glabrum), air American perennial herb 30 to 90 cm high, with narrow pointed leaves 5 to 25 cm long and many small flowers and fruits borne in terminal panicles. It belongs in the buck wheat family and grows in damp spots.

a demigod... The stretching demigod born as a rope on Maui. He could stretch from Molokaʻi to Hawaiʻi and wade in the deep sea. His exploits explain gashes, ledges, and footprints on the islands. He restored the sun and, with his brother Nīheu, rescued his mother, Hina, who had been stolen (not, perhaps, against her will) by a Molokaʻi chief.  Emerson calls him a god of jugglers. (Malo 227-229, Emerson note).

a major god... One of the four great gods. His name was not coupled with innumerable epithets, as were the names of the others. His companion and leader was Kāne. They were renowned as kava drinkers, and they found water in many places. Three days of the lunar month were sacred to Kanaloa — the twenty-fourth (Kāloa-Kū-Kahi), the twenty-fifth (Kāloa-Kū-Lua), and the twenty-sixth (Kāloa-Pau). Some considered him a god of the sea, and in Christian times he was equated with Satan. Emerson (Malo 111) gives a healing prayer to him as god of squids (he had this form, as well as that of the ʻalaʻala-pū-loa weed).

small endemic trees (Broussaisia arguta), with large, oval, toothed leaves, in the saxifrage family; the small flowers and berries are arranged in wide, convex clusters. The flowers of one form have bluish-green petals; of another, red, another white, An old belief was that eating the fruit helped in fecundity; the increase of chiefs was compared to a fruiting kanawao. Varieties are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula.

the "leading god among the great gods" (HM 42); a god of creation and the ancestor of chiefs and commoners; a god of sunlight, fresh water, and forests (Thrum, p. 82) to whom no human sacrifices were made. In prayers to Kāne (HM 53-55) his name is followed by more than seventy epithets. Kanaloa was his constant companion, but Kāne's name always preceded. Twelve sacred paradisic islands lay off the Hawaiian group "within easy reach," visible on the distant horizon at sunrise and sunset. One is Kāne-hūnā-moku (Kāne hidden island) where Kāne and Kanaloa lived. (HM 67) The twenty-seventh night of the lunar month was sacred to Kāne. see (UL 257-259) for a famous chant to Kāne. lit., male.
name of the 27th night of the lunar month.
name of a sacred star, seen by priests as portending great misfortune, as the death of a chief; perhaps a variable like Mira or Algol, or even a nova.

more commonly known as Kapo, this unusual goddess was a sister of Pele and daughter of Haumea. She had a dual nature — as a benevolent hula goddess identified with Laka, and as a fierce goddess of sorcery. At Maunaloa, Molokai, she entered an ʻohe tree and poisoned it (see kālaipāhoa). She saved Pele from being raped by Kamapuaʻa by sending her flying vagina (kohe lele) as a lure. Kama followed this to Koko Head, Oahu, where it left an imprint. Later Kapo hid it in Kalihi Valley. (HM 187, 212-213). Kapo was also called Kapokohelele. As a hula goddess, one of her forms was the hala-pepe tree, branches of which were therefore placed on hula altars. lit., Kapo red dotted with dark.

a method of feeding children or high-born persons as a special honor; the recipient held back his head and opened his mouth; the morsel of poi was dropped into his mouth; much enjoyed by children as a game.
center tapa under which the stone was hidden in the game of pūhenehene.
middle finger of the hand.
reason, cause.
name of a star in the northern sky that served as guide to mariners.
the Milky Way.
depression between collarbone and neck.
indicating plural, much less used than nā and mau except in the compounds kauhale, kaukolu, kauwahi.
expressing superlative, preceded by hoʻi or mai hoʻi.
to discuss.
name of a district on Hawaiʻi. see epithets, kua₁, Kuehu Lepo, mākaha₁, wehi₃, and chant, kiʻekiʻe.

outcast, pariah, slave, untouchable, menial; a caste which lived apart and was drawn on for human sacrifices (these traditional meanings carried great opprobrium). Later it was used in the Bible and in formal correspondence to translate servant. Lesser chiefs who served higher chiefs were called kauā maoli (see aliʻi poʻe kauā). see haʻalele loa₂, lauʻī pekepeke, makawela, and below for insulting names for kauā, and pejorative -a and (Malo 68–72).
to detain, gently request to remain.
wind name. lit., the raging rain.
to look or move straight ahead: to gaze.
gentle, as a breeze; light.
a variety of sweet potato.
World War.
revolutionary war.
any type of kauā who works hard, vassal. lit., oppressed kauā.
Kauaʻi (name of one of the Hawaiian islands), Kauaʻi person.  (perhaps kau, to place + -aʻi, transitivizer.)
first harvest of small sweet potatoes, others being left to grow larger.
a boisterous person who speaks loudly and gestures wildly, making a spectacle of himself.
name of a star associated with Kohala, Hawaiʻi.

• season after season;  
   • fig., always and forever.
Kauā branded with dot in the middle of the forehead. lit., dotted outcast.
sham battle.
a lua fighting stroke.
civil war, internal war.
Kauā with tattooed label on temples. lit., outcast surrounded forehead.
to drag, pull along.
a lua fighting stroke.
a commoner elevated to chieftainship.
cavalry; cavalry war. lit., horse war.
to carry a person supported by arms over the shoulders of two persons, as one drunk or sick, or for one person to half carry and half drag another person. lit., place like a kite.
a constellation, possibly Corona Borealis.
i ka ua mea..... due to (the thing known as)...
ambuscade. lit., lying-down war.
the southern sky where the star Lipo may be seen; the rising of the star Lipo. Variants are kauana Lepo, kauana Lewa, and kauana Liolio-iWawau.
a star, possibly Sirius. lit., placed in holy stillness. Other names are Kauluikua, Kauʻōpae, Hoʻokelewaʻa, ʻAʻā and ʻĀikikauelono. This star was used by navigators and fishermen.
winter, cold season.
a single generation from father to son.
drudge; to be a drudge.

• combat, 
   • debate.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the soaring petrel.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the petrel trespasses.
a strong mountain wind, often destructive, at Lahaina, Maui. lit., the red rain [referring to red soil washed away by a storm].
kind of soft, reddish porous stone used for polishing and smoothing and as sinker for octopus lure.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the swinging petrel.
too short, as a dress; to hang short.
Var. spellings of kauwele and kauwelu.
to dig up the past, to review the past.
to move up and down as the waves, or as in dancing; to undulate.

group of houses comprising a Hawaiian home, formerly consisting of men's eating house, women's eating house, sleeping house, cook-house, canoe house, etc. Term was later used even if the home included but a single house, and is sometimes used for hamlet or settlement. It is used without an article.  lit., plural house.
tabernacle. lit., movable house.
South Hampton.
half-mast; to raise at half-mast.

• tangled, snarled, of vines. 
   • fig., in trouble.
lashing, as of thatching sticks to house post.
name of an unknown lazy man.
to fasten horizontal thatching sticks and plates of a house with rope.
to open, unfold, as a tapa; to expand, as a flower in bloom.
to lose consciousness, as in an epileptic seizure; heart attack, stroke.
to pursue in order to harm, chase, to run after, run and fetch.
fruit season.
desire.
state of pregnancy.
spelling, orthography; to write down, note. lit., place word.
house ridgepole, main ridge pole. see illus. 1, illus. 2, illus. 4
edge of a precipice.
gathering of fish in schools near the surface of the sea.
a lua fighting stroke. Uhumākaʻikaʻi was the name of the giant uhu fish that dragged Kawelo for two days in his canoe from Waiʻanae to Niʻihau and back to Waiʻanae.

a native tree in the buckthorn family (Colubrina oppositifolia), found only on Oʻahu and Hawaiʻi, with opposite leaves, ovate and to 15 cm long. 
   • Its hard wood was valued for spears and tools, and was not reputed to be poisonous.     Called oʻa on Maui.

   • ceremonial readorning of images with feathers.
hard, reddish rock resembling ʻalā.
a kind of black, tough sugar cane.
temple ceremonies, during which images were readorned with feathers.
to loiter about the door of a house as though desiring food gifts; one who does so. lit., placed [at the] door.
chiropractor. lit., bone-breaking doctor.
canoe with a single outrigger float.
veterinary. lit., animal doctor.
obstetrician.
to depend on; one depended on (kau, to place + -kaʻi, transitivizer).
surgeon. lit., cutting doctor.
medical doctor.
star name.
osteopath. lit., massage doctor.
cucumber (Cucumis sativus), introduced. listed in (Ellis 1825, p. 247). (Nah. 11.5) , (Neal 811).
lit., sea cucumber.
name of a star that rises with Kawelolani in the month of ʻIkuā.
to legislate, make or enact laws; legislator, lawmaker, legislation; legal.
dentist. lit., tooth doctor.
obstetrician.
heap of stones used as a temporary altar.
bird snare; to set or fix a bird snare.
hemorrhoid or exterior obstruction to bowel evacuation.
class of chiefs of lesser rank than the high chief, the father a high chief and the mother of lower rank but not a commoner.
tap-tap, as of tattoo needle when it pierces the skin.
temporary rope fence.
nimbleness, joy; nimble, agile, active, joyful, as one leaping for joy.
to fall or lie on a slant, as rain; slanting.
cousin.
short for kau ʻokoʻa, to place separately; to separate.
to continue or persevere in a straight course.
election season, election.
triple, trinity, group of three.
to walk with a cane (koʻo); to lean on, rely on, depend on. fig., old and infirm.
candlestick, lamp stand. lit., place light.
a rocky islet off Niʻihau.  [Kaʻula was famous for its birds: see examples].
name of a wind associated with Pōhakuloa, Maui.
a sea bird.
prophet, seer, magician.
wick.
growing in a tree; to be in a tree; all kinds of epiphytic plants.
cloudless, standing out clearly, plainly seen.
chain. lit., iron rope.
fuse. lit., ignition rope.
rope for lassooing or ensnaring.
bracelets.  lit., dangling rope.
cord for marking tapa.
line from mast to stern.
tall strap.
drawstring, rope or cord to pull on.
halyard.
to hang up, as to dry in the sun. (kau, to hang + laʻi, transitivizer).
line from mast to bow (ihu).

to talk too much of one's family affairs or ancestors, to tell the cherished stories, and chants of one's ancestors (a taunt to those who reveal too much of the Hawaiian past). lit., to dry out the bones, meaning to expose the bones of the ancestors, a crime.
type of pink, smooth, somewhat porous stone.
to sun, bleach in the sun; sun bath; to talk too much of family and ancestors (cf. kaulaʻi iwi).
leather rope, lassoing rope, lariat, strap.
lariat of tanned leather.
line from forward outrigger boom (ʻiako) to prow to strengthen the boom in storms.
lacings, cords as those by which the coconut knee drum (pūniu hula) was tied to the high of the player.
reins, cheek line.
clothesline. lit., line to dry clothes.
towline.
swivel rope.
towline.
rope to tether, as horse, cow, or pig.
cord on which flowers are strung into a lei; cluster of fruit or flowers growing together on a stem like a lei; streamer.
lacing, as for shoes or corset.
shoelace.
rigging.
halter. lit., horse rope.
line running from the prow of a canoe to the after end, used to lash the ʻahu, or mat, used for protection from high seas. lit., old woman line.
name of a star.
rope made of willow or other green bark or branch. lit., green cord.
sisal rope.
ship line of any kind.
broken rope, string.
resting place, place to put things, placement; restful, quiet (kau, to place + -lana, nominalizer).
heap of stones.
land administrator.
name of a star, Acubeus; a poetic name for the west.
resting place of Kāne, said to be on the islet of Kaʻula off Niʻihau; also a poetic name for the west.
bridge, trestle.
the position of the moon; the traditional lunar calendar.
a squid (family Sepiolidae), Euprymna scolopes. lit., resting mūheʻe.
heir by word-of-mouth rather than by written will; to make a will verbally; a verbal will.
place where canoes stop, as while fishing.
to rely on the chief, to support the chief, to put confidence in the chief.
sprit line.
strong outrigger lashing used on deepwater canoes, probably so called because of the hardness of ʻōhiʻa wood.
saddle girth. lit., stomach rope.
leash. lit., rope held hand.
sheet from boom to after outrigger boom (ʻiako hope).
line, as to raise a sail. lit., sliding line.
line holding in place the canoe pāʻū, cover.
ship shroud.
watch chain.
cable.
streak of lightning.
bridle, reins; to bridle. lit., mouth chain
line extending from sail tip to the ʻiako, boom, on the edge of the canoe.
prophetess, priestess.
to sell leis; to hang leis.
too high; too short, as a dress. fig., insecure, infirm.
to rest, hang, be placed.
insecurity.
to take flight; soaring, on the wing.
exclamation, stress; to accent in music.
extraordinary, over and above the ordinary, extra, added on, additional, supplemental, random, excess.
insertion; to insert.
an ʻoʻopu fish found in brackish water. lit., the long penis.

   • advise, 
   • command. 
    lit., to place the voice.
to hang, be suspended; unsettled.
to show off, play the dandy
to lash.
to creep along, move with a hissing sound, as fire.
hung, suspended, hanging.
name of a star called the chief of the month of Ikiiki because it appears in that month.

• to scatter here and there in small quantities; 
   • to divide or distribute small amounts.

   • equation,

unjust, unreasonable, uneven, unfair.
southeast.
to ride horseback; horseback rider.
probably same as Liolioiwawau, a star name.
to ask frequently, tease; importunate, annoying.

   • to direct attention to, 
   • aim at.

names of several stars begin thus; see:
     Kaulu₂, Southern Cross. also Newe.
     Kaulua₃, one of the many names for the star Sirius; 
     Kauluakoko, Betelgeuse
     Kauluikua, star name, perhaps same as ʻAʻā, Sirius. 
     Kaulu Koʻakoʻa, probably same as ʻAʻā, Sirius. 
     Kaulu Lena,  same as ʻAʻā, Sirius.
     Kauluwena, star name, no data.
ledge, step, jog, as on a cliff. [Elbert lists this form as varying with kaunu in his 1982 l-n doublets list (JPS Lexical Diffusion...) possibly the source of kaulu₇ ?]
Southern Cross.

all species of an endemic genus (Pteralyxia), small trees related to maile, found only on Oʻahu and Kauaʻi, resembling hōeli (Ochrosia) with its shiny, oblong leaves. Fruits are paired, red, ovoid, and each contains one large winged seed.
same as ʻālaʻa (Planchonella), a tree.
same as āulu₅, and lonomea, Sapindus oahuensis, a tree.
neighborhood, locality, place.

a trickster demigod born as a rope. In human form with his strong hands he created surf by breaking the waves; he created small dogs by breaking Kū-ʻīlio-loa (Kū long dog) into pieces. He made the sea salty by draining it and spitting it out. Makaliʻi gave him his nets and he entangled and killed Haumea. (HM 436-437). He defeated Lonoka‘eho and gained control of Koʻolau, Oahu (For. 5:370-371). lit., the inspired one.

• double canoe, 
   • pair, span, yoke, 
   • two of a kind; 
   • to put together or pair, to yoke or harness together, 
   • to double in quantity; 
   • coupled. 
   • fig., two-natured.
name of a month. See (Kep. 89).

one of the many names for the star Sirius; according to some reports, a constellation. The name may be qualified by the terms koko (said to be Betelgeuse), Lena (Sirius), Mōhaʻi (or Haʻi Mōhaʻi), Okaoka.
to harness or put two horses together.
ledge or terrace.

name of the Hawaiian newspaper printed by students of the Hawaiian language at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, begun in 1971. lit., the growing bitter yam [or happiness; see hoi₁ and hoi₂ for word play]. [online here at Ka Ulu Hoi Index]
star name, perhaps same as ʻAʻā, Sirius.
probably same as ʻAʻā, Sirius. (cf. Maori Te-Kokota; the present Hawaiian form may have metathesized from an earlier ʻOkaʻoka)
to decorate, adorn, especially with greenery.
glowing, bright-colored, colorful.
swarming; innumerable.
taboo ceremony in honor of the akua loa, long god, of the makahiki festival.
star name, no data.
sacrifice, offering; to make a sacrifice or offering.
food offering to the gods.
very heavily laden; bearing a heavy load, especially of one drenched with water. fig., extremely sad.
native mistletoes.
period or time of sickness.
similar to kau ka maka, to desire, to long to see, to think of fondly (ON 1613).
ocean sunfish (Mola mola). lit., big eyes placed.
to overlook faults of others. lit., to place shade.
paper mulberry too old to be used for tapa.
method of catching birds by tying a caterpillar and a stick at one end of a string; when the bird swallows the caterpillar the stick lodges in his throat.
regular session, as of legislature.
hanger for ʻumeke, bowls.
marks showing rhythm in songs.
rack to hold fish poles.
stick about 10 cm long with holes down its middle, used to hold gunwales in place while they are being sewed on with sennit.
to splice, mend a fracture with a splint; to fasten canoe gunwale; wooden canoe clamp.
perched high.
uncertain, hesitant.
to point out or determine boundaries of a moʻo land division.
too short; shrinking away, as in distaste.
wind squall.
placement, hanging, appearance.
count (title of nobility).
chanting.
voice used in choral singing, e.g. countertenor or alto.
four (formerly tubers were counted by fours; four was a formulistic number). [traditional 4-based counting: kāuna 4; kaʻau 40; lau 400; mano 4,000; kini 40,000; lehu 400,000] (see pākāuna.)
countess.
quotation marks.
var. of kaunalipo.
perseverance; to persevere.
to discover, perceive.

a native dodder (Cuscuta sandwichiana), belonging to the morning-glory family, a leafless, parasitic vine, growing densely on other plants. The numerous, slender, orange stems are used for orange leis to represent the island of Lānaʻi, as designated by the Territorial legislature in 1923.

a mollusk (Vermetidae). In adult stage it becomes solidly fixed to rocks; cuts resulting from stepping on it are considered deadly poisonous by Hawaiians. The mollusk was believed somehow related to the dodder.
a coarse, tough seaweed (Galaxaura rugosa), calcified and inedible, resembling kaunaʻoa₁ in being yellow to gold in color.
lit., mālolo (flying fish) kaunaʻoa, so called because this plant was spread over mālolo caught in a canoe to keep them from escaping. Sometimes called mālolo or pōlolo.

a greenish-yellow dodder vine (Cassytha filiformis), belonging to the laurel family, cosmopolitan in the tropics. It is coarser than the native orange dodder (Cuscuta sandwichiana). lit., swollen kaunaʻoa.
lit., upland kaunaʻoa.
countess. lit., female count.
slow, lagging, delaying.
to hang short.
holding on precariously. lit., resting on the edges.
Niʻihau.
a rough seaweed (Galaxaura rugosa).
a large Hawaiian bird.
pole set up as indicative of taboo.
a lua fighting stroke.
insincere love-making.
to drag, haul, draw along, tow.
yolk or white of an egg.
loud type of prayer, usually at makahiki festivals. cf. wōwō, hoʻokāwōwō.
an office in the king's train (And); unarmed spy in enemy country (Malo 202, Emerson note).
New Testament.
Old Testament.
white of an egg.
placed, apart, separate.
high shelf or place where chiefs hung or placed (kau) their clothes.
to express admiration or praise of a chief, as in chant.
yolk of an egg.
name for the star Sirius.
name of a star.
to drag a canoe, especially if unfinished, from the mountain forest to the shore to be finished.
to walk straight.
to appear irregular or crooked.
common var. of kaupoku, ridgepole, highest point, roof, ceiling, attic...
blockage, barrier, etc.
to draw the color line; to show race prejudice. lit., to make a skin boundary.

   • mark a border or boundary, 
   • set a deadline; deadline.
birth control.
fence or boundary between one patch of land (waena) and another.
